content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												OK, first of all, this game is not really an RPG. I know it reads up there on the genre description here on Steam, but this game is more of an Action RPG then anything else.So, basically you enter this world where humans are fighting against demons and vice versa. In your first playthrough you start playing on the Light campaign, as one of the humans. The controls function like any other RPG, except here the combat is more fast paced. You don't go around and do quests and there is very little dialog. What you do is basically kill everything you see, and collect as much gold as you can. With the gold you collect, you can equip better weapons, armor, and bring more potions with you each time. There are quite a lot of races/classes that you gain as you play (some by completing levels, and some are special classes that you get after collecting all of the gold in the game).The game itself is fun. It's obviously not a modern game. The graphics are dated, but they're not ugly or anything. The soundtrack is lacking, with only a few songs that you keep hearing over and over, but hey, at least they're good. The gameplay is simple and intuitive, but I have to warn you that the hitboxes are very small, and the game can be a bit difficult sometimes. I finished the game on medium but even then I had to replay most levels quite a few times. After you finish the game for the first time, you can play the game now on the Dark campaign and get a different perspective.Even though the game is from 2003 its It puts a lot of new games to shame. It's challenging, fun, and has a lot of content. I recommend.

Most of the plot points don't make sense, like WHY THE HECK AM I IN A FREAKING FIERY VOLCANO PLACE, WIELDING A DANG ICE BLADE... Just why.No multiplayer._________________________________________________________________________________All in all, an fun game. GO GET IT!

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Enclave is a fantasy action-adventure game. The rift that separated the Enclave of Magic from the Outlands is slowly closing, and heroes emerge from both sides, either to defend or conquer the Enclave.Pros: The game offers two campaigns, first the light campaign where you defend the Enclave from the invaders, and then the dark campaign where you are a minion seeking the glory of conquest. As the story progresses, you find or unlock additional equipment and up to six characters (per campaign) to play as. At the start of each chapters, you get to pick your character and equipment, limited by how much gold you found in each mission. For the most part, you can backtrack as much as you want for each missions, and replay any of them at any time if you missed out on some gold and want to try to do better (allowing you to select more equipment).Cons: I don't know why this was tagged as an RPG on Steam, 'cause it sure isn't: you have no stats, no upgrades, no character interaction or dialog choice. You don't even really purchase and manage an inventory, gold serves as "points" that determine how much equipment you can bring in a mission, being able to swap out at full value any item in between chapters. It is a Hack & Slash in the most basic fashion, battles consisting merely of slashing in the wind, only knowing whether you hit anything if damage numbers appear, while the AI is monstrously bad (enemies just jiggle about, only occasionally chasing assuming you don't break line of sight, like passing behind a chair). Voice acting is horrible, the story is rather poor, character progression is absent, and having up-to-date resolution doesn't save the graphics that have aged so badly that most 3D Fantasy early access indie titles are doing better than this blocky 2-Gen-Old world. Verdict: ★☆☆☆☆ - May it rot in your backlogIt's not horrible, but it is pretty bad by today's standards. I simply cannot get myself invested enough to ever play it again, leave alone complete a playthrough of even the first campaign. Maybe once upon a time it was considered a good game, but I can't see how I could recommend it to anyone, even for the low price.P.S.: At the time of my review, there were dozens of Steam Recommendations that were fake, just to raise the score. They all said "gg" or "ggg" with usernames starting by X or ending by XYZ and all had the same account picture (once my review topped the store page for a few months, the fake reviews were removed or altered to make them more subtle). Seriously, dev/fans? You sank so low that you wanted to "cheat" the Steam score to make more sales?—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Let me start by saying, I REALLY tried to like this game. And at first? I loved it. Enclave is an action-based RPG where you hack and slash your way through levels (depending on your class) all while collecting gold so you can afford better gear at a shop you visit in-between levels. Collecting gold is HUGELY important. In later levels archers are OP with their damage and warriors are brutally tanky. You NEED to collect gold otherwise you stand no chance. Let me also state one thing. THERE IS NO ADWARE IN THIS GAME. THESE MANY REVIEWS THAT SAY SO ARE OLD, AND HAVE NOT CHANGED EVEN THOUGH THE ADWARE HAS BEEN REMOVED. So what does this game have going for it?+From 2002 I never would have expected these kinds of graphics. +The soundtrack is amazing. +And the sound effects aren't too shabby either. +The level design and placement of enemies is genius.+The destruction in this game is fantastic. In buildings during sieges the roof can fall on your head, fatally damaging you. You can slash the beam of a wooden watch tower and bring it falling to the ground. Crates can be broken into flying pieces by explosives that are essentially flying wooden weapons.UNFORTUNATELY.-The story is really...bland. A 3 year old that watched lord of the rings could have thought this story up.-The enemies are very generic and repetitive. Again, a 3 year old that watched lord of the rings could have created these extremely generic characters.-The voice acting is mediocre. -The AI is nonsensical is how it acts. Enemies are jumping and breakdancing all over the place while you're supposed to be in a serious fight.-The combat. The core element of ARPGs, the COMBAT. Is the worst combat I have ever seen in an RPG in my entire life.  Ranged weapons work around a little dot you see in the center of your screen. Place it over an enemy and shoot, and you hit. Miss by an inch and you miss completely. It's pathetic. The melee combat is even worse. You just spam left mouse click to swing a sword aimlessly, missing tiny enemies completely unless you can get down to their level most of the time. Your shield is basically useless because there's a delay between raising it and lowering it that you could have used to get attacks in, that your enemies WILL use to attack you. The swordplay is also very unresponsive. I mouse click twice and suddenly my character is doing a 4-move sword swinging fiasco while I'm right clicking and trying to raise my shield. So an enemy pummels me while my character is having fun being some kind of sword dancer.Even if you get this for free like I did I would not recommend playing it. Maybe this kind of gameplay was good in an ARPG once, but at the same time, RUNESCAPE had better combat than this. So I could never condone a game that flops on its main element so badly. STAY AWAY.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I suppose its worth a try, but do play on Easy difficulty the first time, because you will find yourself dieing quite a bit, even on Easy mode. Its a game that doesn't take combat lightly, especially against certain enemies. You need to use your shield, as well as avoiding enemy attacks to maximize your combat efficiency and save on health.The game is also kind of a collect-a-thon in where each level has treasure for you to find hidden throughout, you also get a mandatory sum of gold after each level. However, if you get more gold hidden in the levels, you can equip yourself with better gear and more potions at a time at the start of each level. The way you spend money is well, you don't exactly spend it like you normally would. Everything costs a certain amount and you will always have the amount of gold prior to "spending" it on your loadout. So the more gold you have, the better gear you can have, and more potions too.The combat is a bit lackluster, in fact the hitboxes seem damn near god awful and random. Also the damage you deal seems vague at best, its random seeming sometimes as well. I guess I can't quite nail the pattern down. Ever.The levels work on a checkpoint system and there is no quicksaving/quickloading. So if you die before a checkpoint, you're screwed, and have to start the level over again. Also I'm not sure if you can use the checkpoints more than once each or not, never died more than once per checkpoint. Well its the type of checkpoint where it teleports you to the point with full health, but your progress is not altered.Still, at that price its worth a play, even if it can only keep your attention long enough to play the Light Campaign. Oh yeah, theres two campaigns. Light Campaign, and the Dark Campaign, available after you beat the Light Campaign.

number of helpful: 73 of 104 people (70%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Enclave is a gem of a game from the original X-Box era back in 2003. Its a third or first person medieval fantasy hack and slash with engaging combat and exceptional environments. For the rogue in all us there is a dark campaign where you play as several evil classes like assassin, berserker, lich and sorceress to name a few. If there are any good hearts out there, you also have the light campaign with their human counterpart classes such as knight, huntress, druid, wizard and half-ling. Each campaign lasted me a fun and joyous seven hours. At the start of each level you select your class and assign their equipment from the money you have. Nothing is permanently bought, so if you want expensive armor and a weak weapon with a few potions, you can do it or if zero potions, expensive weapons and armor is more to your liking go for it. The money is never spent, just assigned. These classes, play styles and different equipment go a long way to making each play through different, even if its your twentieth time on a level.So why is this game so good? Let's start with the controls and movement. While this was an X-Box game, there doesn't seem to be controller support. You're stuck with your keyboard and rebindable keys. Its more than that though, your character seems to have a good sense of movement. You'll climb ladders, duck to crawl through tunnels, jump up boxes and over collapsed bridges. Even jump from rooftop to rooftop. Each class has its own speed. For the most part the heroes of the light campaign feel slower than their dark counterparts. Knights and berserkers move slow, while half-lings and goblins are the fastest. There is no run button, heroic classes are so slow that it really feels like you need to fight.Getting there is half the fun, but along the way you'll of course find enemies and you've got the fantastic combat to take them out with. I can't call it deep combat so much as its fun. Each class can have a melee weapon that you really just mouse click bash to flail it around. Each weapon has its own strength, speed and range. Others have enchantments that will light enemies on fire. Most classes also have a shield too. Hold the right mouse button to have your shield up to block arrows and wow you will be blocking a lot of arrows. With some enemies that can fire a shotgun of bolts at you, it becomes mandatory if you're going to survive at close range.To add some depth there, each time your shield gets bashed, that will knock it away for a split second leaving you open to attack. So if two archers time it just right they can break through your defenses. This goes for enemies with shields too. They're just like you, when their shield is up, you need to knock it down to hurt them.Wizards, sorceresses, lich and druids have magic. Each magician has a magic meter that refills over time.  So if you run out from fire balling an enemy, you've got to wait, where the enemies see your weakness and will rush at you. You can equip two spell staffs, so you have a variety there in the level. A lot of the spells make the game easier. Plenty of them seek out enemies and turn in the air to hit them. Instead of a shield, the right mouse will raise a force field, but I never used it that much, since mages are such long range classes. Some staffs also have a summoning ability to raise an ally to help you. Oh and the spells can't get blocked. You still take damage.Form there, non magic classes can also have a long range bow or cross bow. Even the knight and grenaders can use them, but you need to equip them at the start of each level, you can't just find one. I've gotta say crossbows and bows are far too difficult to accurately hit anything. Sure melee enemies running to you will take arrows til they're dead. Its shooting the other archers that becomes incredibly difficult. They can dodge arrows just as good as any human player. Its difficult to accurately hit them, so to compensate, there are several different tricks. You can load several bolts into a bow at once by pressing the right mouse button. Then release so one of them will hit its target if not all to instantly kill a close enemy. There are also fire bolts that will ignite enemies or the ground on fire. The abilities add some interesting facets to the game when you're forced to play as an assassin for the dark campaign's original character.You have a quick health potion button that really plays into combat, because you need to chug the potion. Its not just instant energy, so if you're getting beaten to death, you need to hide and chug the potion before you can attack or defend again. It adds a lot to the combat and gives the enemies a better chance.You'll need to unlock the classes as you go through the game. This means you'll be rescuing your comrades in their levels. With them freed, they'll temporarily aide you, fight shoulder to shoulder with you and guide you to the next part. They can die too, but as long as you've saved them and complete the level, they're unlocked.Enclave puts you into incredible environments and assets are not used from level to level. So each level has a completely different look and feel. Crypts, tombs, caves, castles, lava caverns, shadowy towns, human towns. There is a ton of variety here. Between the light and dark campaigns only a few levels get reused among the two. Even if it is a shared level, you start from the opposite end of it, to make it feel fresher. The levels feel like they're just the right amount of time. Each level has plenty of exploration and a lot of levels feel open enough where you can look around without feeling like you're forced down a corridor. They never overstay their welcome. I never think of it as a chore, because there's always something new and beautiful to see around every corner.The pre rendered cut scenes and menus are pretty dated with low resolution quality so they don't look as gorgeous as the game itself. Not that the game itself is high definition, but over a decade later it still looks amazing. The only thing lacking are the ground textures. Grassy fields could have used Oblivion style grass, but for a game that came out when Morrowind did it still looks better than its contemporaries.Its not all roses and sunshine in this dark enchanted world. The game goes from a fun treat and knuckles down on you in later levels to beat you down. I appreciated the challenge, even if some levels took me five minutes to make it across a bridge. If you die, you need to restart the level. To balance it out, if you can make it to a checkpoint, you will respawn there when you die. There's just one catch. You need enough gold collected in that level to respawn. I'm thankful for the checkpoints even at a cost. Having each revive cost gold gives you incentive to return to each level after you complete it. Oh by the way, you only keep the gold if you beat the level. So if you died ten times, you spent one hundred gold, so you can return to the level, not die and get an extra hundred gold to spend. Assuming you collected what you had before. That's the beauty with all the exploration, you can find things or miss them.You won't get limited to combat, there are some puzzles and a few brief, yet fun turret sections that don't tie you to the turrets. The bosses are giant and feel engaging without being overwhelming or frustrating. A giant dragon, a huge lava monster and the mega evil boss has you shooting its hanging heart. If that wasn't enough for you, there are unlockable mini games that are actually fun. You'll find maps in levels that will unlock games like a survival mode and a cool turret gallery.The music is also something to take note of. Its great and really fits the medieval epicness of the game. Its beautiful and touching, but with big and bold moments too.Once again, this is just a gem of a game that I would have paid full price for when it was $50. Thanks to someone from Sweden for giving me the game!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Nice visuals and sound are trying to cover the remaining gaps.The game has more than 10 years, although it is at pretty good technical level. When the game starts, greets us a little rather dynamic and impressive intro, but which fulfills its role as it should be - give the stories being pretext for threshing, which is to take place.  After this introduction, we have to choose side for which we'll be fighting for - good or evil. I chose the path of light (I'm such a thoroughly good man). Interestingly, this choice is important. Because each party has a completely different missions and different course of the game. It is worth to finish the game twice (that's what I did).After passing each stage we get access to new characters. Accessories, or rather equipment, does not impress anything in particular more fasting RPG fans. Besides, the Enclave is not rpg, although it may give such an impression, especially the world of game, full of mages, orcs and dragons. But returning to the equipment. We have swords, axes, hammers, but also bows or crossbows, ideally proven in the battles at distance. There is also something for the defense - shields and armor.  Everything we gain as you progress in the game. As far as we can afford it ... After each mission in "shop" there are new, better, items, and to buy them, we must have enough gold. Installment system in the world Enclave unfortunately does not exist, so the only solution is to keep your eyes wide open. Gold is scattered throughout the stages - often in various nooks and burrows.As I said, the game was created a few years ago, but the graphic design looks passably well and still manages to attract the eyes to the screen without feeling disgust. Game menu looks impressive, being a foretaste of what awaits us in the game. Graphics look nothing less than more, as nicely. Textures are highly varied, and also flattering for a single pixel. Also, light effects and shadows have their charm. I must also mention about the interesting animation of monsters (large stock of movements). I have only caveat to NPC's faces. During expression in the cutscenes look like they had founded mask. The movable is only jaw, which gives quite unsightly visual effect. But the water ... the water looks beautiful. It is true that the whole persists to today's productions, but heck, this game is already on his neck showing its age! Soundtrack is another strong element of Enclave. The soundtrack is great, and the sound effects round out the rest.The game is based roughly on the exploration of stages, which generously dotted with monsters, gold and various necessary to complete the map objects. We have a whole range of enemies. Some may complain about the level of difficulty, because the monsters were waving the weapon incredibly fast and agile. You need to skillfully put tactic, otherwise death will take us quickly. I played at the level of medium, namely the middle, and I have to admit that the level of irritation pierced several times the national average.The combat system and the game itself falls moderately. The title is linear. Is it negative? I do not know, maybe, but for me not having any meaning. The combat system is extremely simple. Click the mouse and our soldier is attacking what he has in his hands. We will not experience any finesse. Attack, Defense, that's all.However, this game was able to catch me on a couple of good hours. Somehow I got this game for free. And I'm not sure if it's worth it for the moment these 6 euros. But do not hesitate to buy this game if it will be on promotion.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is something else, truly. For starters it has beautiful graphics for it's time, it look wonderful and you can tell the developers worked really hard on them. The same goes for the weapon and shields, they are very nice to look at, and you feel a sense of accomplishment when you can buy that sword, axe, staff, that completely obliterates your enemies in 2-3 hits.Now, gameplay, the controls are very solid and quite easy to control. At times it feels the mouse is a tad slow when it comes moving around and viewing everything, but it's easy to adjust in the menu. Also, there is no delay in the buttons so it is very nice. The fighting is very unispired and makes combat feel more like a chore. After completing the main objective in the quest, towards the end of the game I just bolted out of there. No experience is gained whatsoever, so what's my incentive? Oh, that's right, gold!Gold, you must collect gold througout the campaign. Some which is hidden VERY well and is extremely UNFAIR to get. When I say unfair, I mean that in this game, there are VERY FEW checkpoints. And if you aim to 100% this, you are going to pull out  your hair. Thing about checkpoints is, if you happen to reach one, but die..you lose gold. And that means you have to start over on the level completely in order to get all gold. Note, you need gold if you want to 100% the guy, buy more items and also  unlock all the characters. Again, it wouldn't be so bad if they weren't in such ridiculous spots. Earlier I said the controls are spot on, which they are, but the way these pots of gold and jewels are placed, it's beyond ridiculous. Storyline, it was very meh. You don't connect the chracters at all and the cutscenes and whatnot are very short and semi-informative. I didn't really play it for the storyline, mainly nostalgic reasons. I played it previously on Xbox and just had to relive this games graphical beauties one more time.Overall, I do recommend this game. And give it a 6/10. The graphics are what really makes this game, but also the nice weapons you purchase as well. The combat is very so so and the story is..well it's a story. Fun game if you want to hack and slash, but that's all you're really getting out of it.

content:
Posted: January 3
												A great title for RPG fans though keep in mind this isn't an open world or story-rich experience. There's no loot system here, it's mostly simple linear pathing over two seperate campaigns. You only deviate to find currency collectibles which carry over for the entire game, allowing you to purchase a selection of weapons and armor from a wide arsenal before each mission. That, combined with the ability to change your hero class is what keeps this game fresh and interesting. Combat is similar to Rune but sharper and more customisable - pretty reminiscent of the early 2000's but genuinely fun. Performance wise I've had no issues with Enclave. Actually I was surprised to see it has a decent options menu for such a dated game, which includes support for modern resolution scalings. As far as I'm concerned, Enclave is a damn fine game. Its biggest crime is a lackluster story. Edit: In closing I'd like to address negative feedback for Enclave which concerns an in-game advertisement. You will not be subjected to advertisements when booting Enclave as they no longer exist. It was unfortunately forced in from the new publisher, but has long since been removed.

												The Good:+ Given its age the graphics are pretty decent. Nothing spectacular but I was surprised how good it looked for such an old game+ Multiple characters to fit your own playstyle. content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Interesting game.  I enjoyed what I played of Enclave eventhough it's clearly dated by this point, but unforunately, I decided to uninstall the game and move on because of crash troubles.Enclave plays fairly well.  The controls are straight forward and not overly complicated.  It's easy to dive into it with a minimal tutorial.I wanted to keep playing it, but the game randomly crashes too often (windows 8.1).  You have to reload and start the last mission again, the in-mission checkpoints aren't save points, just start points if you die inside that particular mission.  I found a fix that tells you how to change a line in the config file from Direct3D to OpenGL.  This fix stabilizes Enclave quite a bit so that it doesn't crash quite as often, but it still crashes.  I found that your chances of crashing increase if you die and restart the mission, or die and load at a checkpoint.  Maybe someday I will revisit it and try to finish it, but due to the crash problems, I have to give Enclave a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Enclave is a good game.Now, take my word for what it's worth because I am very, very much biased in favor of this game; I've completed it at least ten times on disc with another two since I purchased it on steam.But, in my opinion, the fact I like it enough to have played it this many times is something of a statement as to it's quality.The pros are easy to list:-Very intuitive.-Fast paced.-Hitboxes are very much what you'd expect.-Hitting someone with a melee weapon has the weight and impact you'd expect.-The way the missions are handled makes shooting for the 100% both very much doable and rewarding.-The paradox of "But I might need it later" never arises. You use what you need, when you need it, and it's bloody satisfying blasting a bunch of armored knights with a bomb.-No serious difficulty spikes; the game picks up the pace as you go along, not suddenly bombards you with something unreasonable you've never seen before.-Stealth works the way you'd expect.-Multiple weapon types that actually feel different and require different timings for their attacks to actually land. Each of the several staves also has a very different main and secondary attack.-Has a great cast of diverse characters for you to play as that actually have an impact on their playstyle; each of them has different equipment that they can use, different size hitboxes, different health and damage modifiers.-Locational damage is very accurate and makes aiming for the most vulnerable part of your enemy a good way of removing them. This mechanic works well with the fact different characters have different armor types for different sections of their body, depending on armor class.The cons are also easy to list:-It's too short.-Sound design. On multiple occasions I found the voice lines got sped up, raised in pitch or what-have-you.-It's duration leaves something to be desired.-Soundtrack is not that great.-It's very, very brief.-It's pretty old, and hasn't aged too well in most areas.-It's gone too quickly.-The story is stupid. Not even funny stupid, just flat out stupid. It's not offensive or anything, though.-And yeah, it's length is insufficient.-By now I'm so proficient in this game I can complete any mission of either campaign with just the starting bow and arrows, armorless and without consuming health potions. Send help.-It's clock-time isn't all too great.Yes, you could say I'm crazy, but I'd be far too busy hearing you over the dying grunts of an orc being shot in the neck by my magical arrows to notice.Far as I'm concernd, 10/10. Would shoot hundreds of enemies in the neck with magical armor-piercing arrows again.-Sleepy

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												One of the jankiest, most unbalanced games I've played - I love it. The graphics hold up fairly well and the game supports modern widescreen resolutions (although the menus are all pre-rendered to 4:3). The game does seem to crash without warning sometimes, but not even that was enough to prevent me from enjoying everything this game had to offer. Completing both campaigns took me about eight hours.The combat is very basic, but I found it oddly satisfying. Just hit things until they die. In each level you can choose from a selection of characters and then outfit them with various weapons, magic and equipment using the gold you find scattered in each area. Finding the most overpowered loadouts and putting them to use is a lot of fun and makes the difficulty of the later levels a lot more tolerable.The story and setting of Enclave certainly could be described as 'generic western fantasy,' but I did find some of the visual designs to be quite interesting and original. The music is fairly standard stuff, but is effective. I would recommend this game if you like old PC fantasy games and can put up with the possiblity of crashes.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												Most of my experience with Enclave has been via the DotEmu and original Xbox releases. So don't let my Steam stats fool you.Enclave was released at a time when third person action games were really gaining an edge: the 6th generation (early 2000s). What sets Enclave apart is its RPG-like character unlocking, character swapping, upgrades, and back stories. During the 5th generation (PS1/N64/Sega Saturn) we had the likes of Tenchu and Syphon Filter, but nothing quite like Enclave. While the likes of Blood Rayne and Prince of Persia were backed by bigger budgets and better marketing, it was games like Enclave and MDK 2 that injected the third person action genre with this thing called "replay value".Whether you're a fan of the steam-punk aesthetic or third person action games or just want a fun (and very cheap) boredom killer, Enclave is a worthy addition to your PC gaming library.

content:
Posted: February 13
												I have a strange suspision that Enclave might not be a very good game. On the other hand, I enjoyed this third person hack 'n' slash enough to finish both of its campaigns (the Light one and the Dark), so maybe it's not all that bad either.I wish I knew what the story in this game was about, but it was delivered in the most boring way, so my mind began to wander everytime I was exposed to it, making me unable to take notice. Basically, what you get is something that I like to call "a talking book" - cutscenes showing nothing but an old looking book with a voiceover put on top of it. I guess, all you really need to know is that the good guys fight the bad guys, right? What really matters, is the gameplay......And the gameplay is quite engaging. You play through different levels unlocking new characters that you can choose between at the beginning of each stage. All the playable characters are essentially split between three classes - a fighter for melee combat (sword, axe, hammer + shield), a ranger for ranged combat (bow, crossbow + different types of ammo) and a mage for... ranged combat also, but with MAGIC (various staves that shoot magic missiles). As you go along, you are also provided with better equipement, that you can chose from based on the collective amount of gold you aquired on your adventures. Good stuff.Graphics are quite nice too. Must have been really nice when the game came out. Not much else to say. Overall, I had fun with Enclave. Might recommend.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												I'll try to be as fair as possible with this game. I've played both campaigns on difficult setting with 100% gold, though I had sometimes the urge to just quit the game. First of all, the game looks neat, especially by 2002 standards, the basics of gameplay are pretty easy to learn, the AI is ok and the soundtrack is really atmospheric. So much for the positive aspects of the game.The story is rather lame, run-of-the-mill fantasy with some steampunk elements. But the cutscenes and the presentation of the story make up a little for the weak story. The biggest problem with the game are the messed up hitboxes. And that's a big issue in a hack 'n slash game. Arrows going right through enemies, melee fighters can't hit enemies on stairways if they are below them and missiles going right through massive obstacles. That seems to be intended for magic missiles, but I have noticed some examples where enemy bowmen attacked me through a solid wall while I couldn't hit them, which is pretty frustrating. Also, the 1st person view is rather glitchy, especially in narrow spaces.The balancing is a mess. Sorcerers spam homing missiles at you which drain 1/4 of your life AND do damage over time while most melee fighters are push overs. Since the overall difficulty isn't very high (except for level 13 in the light campaign, that one was really tough), you can rush through most of the levels. You can beat this game with difficult setting and a 100% score in less than 15 hours.I've never even read a single word about bugs referring to this game, but it has its fair share of them. Enemies dropping of cliffs who were supposed to drop gold => 100% no achievable. Traps not triggering. Even important NPCs tend to get stuck in the environment, so you have to start all over again. To be fair, most of the levels are pretty short (sometimes even ridiculously tiny), so that's not a big problem. In summary this game could have used a lot of testing, it feels a little unfinished in some places. But for 5 € you can't go wrong, and as a hack n slash fan you should definitely try this one out.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												I'm not sure why this is advertised as an RPG, as "Enclave" is an Action game. It's not an Action RPG, it's not even an Action game with RPG elements, unless "there are several characters who can use different weapons" counts as one. There are no dialogues, no character stats, no development, no quests, no (semi-) open world to discover, and most importantly of all, there's no role-playing. Naturally an Action game can be a nice experience as well, but sadly, "Enclave" isn't. For once, this is because there's hardly any gameplay. You can walk, jump, attack, and raise your shield in defense - that's it. It's really your basic ego-shooter range of actions. The combat feels incredibly clunky. Your attacks seldomly seem to connect, arrows go through the enemies without causing damage even if they're right in front of you; melee weapons flail wildly and hit everything but your foe. Combat doesn't feel rewarding in any way.The missions are terribly simple as well. You'll always get several aims you need to complete, but it all comes down to "run through the tube-levels and kill everything". There's also a bunch of gold lying around in the levels, granting you access to other (read: stronger) weapons in the next one. The first couple of levels (which I played) feature only two basic types of enemies: small guys and big guys. It's boring, plain and simple.On the pro side, the game environments look really nice. The story seemed alright, too, but I just couldn't be bothered to continue playing the game to find out how it unfolds.I can see why it would still spark nostalgia today for those who played "Enclave" when it was first released, but I just can't recommend buying it now, not even for 99 cents.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												Enclave is a 2002 action game from Starbreeze studios, the studio that went on to develop Chronicles of Riddick, The Darkness, and even Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons. The first few steps of a storied team.Your first mistake will be to think that this is a roleplaying game in the slightest. It is not. Campaigns are divided into an odd 13 missions (14 for Light), and you begin each one by picking a class and loadout. Collecting gold within levels only increases the amount you can purchase with your persistent loadout. This was originally intended as a multiplayer experience, perhaps even solely multiplayer, and it shows. From "You are leaving the mission" messages when you stray too far from the intended game arena, to several "Capture the Castle" missions left wholesale in the Dark Campaign.For the most part this isn't actually a bad thing. It lends itself positively in some other areas - the variety of playstyles is appreciated, and the open-ended levels (whilst obviously meant to accommodate multiple players) make the levels infinitely more interesting than if they were linear. This has all the trappings of a typical Pandemic title in a single-player only package.However, your second mistake is to buy this game, because it's terrible. It's a real letdown that it is. The graphics are nice - much better than the screenshots let on, with some of the Dark Campaign levels being outright beautiful. The character models are comparable to Fable's in quality and art direction, both of which have aged very well, and even the OST is excellent, with battle music and environmental shifting out of each other seamlessly.Though the VA is terrible (narrators aside), it's endearingly so, with exaggerated movements to make up for their lack of emoting that only early 3D titles could provide. Enclave is terrible because it plays terrible. Melee is a wet fish slapping affair, madly bashing the single attack button as you desperately play footsies in a sad display that makes QWOP look elegant, and ranged will see you backpeddle through entire levels as you fish for headshots (along with some hopelessly onesided shootouts against the lazer-sighted AI), In both cases, the hitboxes are completely shot, with both melee and ranged strikes regularly phasing through opponents. Even when you do connect, don't expect any hitstun as you continue dancing like a puppet held by a Parkinson's patient, because this is still a multiplayer title in all but name,It's a disgrace that makes shovelware indie titles look good by comparison. You feel like you're compensating for lag that isn't there, trying to play by the rapidly shifting rules of this broken shoddy gameplay. You shouldn't buy this game, and I don't recommend it. Not because of the "aging graphics", or the pricetag, or even the single save file that gets annoying when your Dark Campaign overwrites the unlocks of your Light Campaign, but because even when compared to its contemporaries, it is an absolute nightmare to actually play.Enclave, a sloppy start to a long career, belongs to the annals of time. You should move on to greener pastures.

												Cool game for its day, to bad I can't get it working well enough to give it a full playthrough. GFX: I'm sure I remember the graphics being amazing way back when pre-rendering was all the fad; which it does use for some things (intro/menus), and scripted scenes in game! Music/SFX: Decent enough music but some sound-fx are a bit odd. Story: Seemed engaging enough, though some of the dialog was a bit hammy.Gameplay: Again, I remember it being great back in the day but I couldn't get it working well enough to tolerate more than 3-4 levels. Game Breaking Bug: Moving the mouse to look around, or change your heading, while moving causes the forward speed to increase by some huge amount. Sometimes the same bug would cause forward movement to continue without any input. Sometimes it would cause mouse look to get a serious case of the jitters.TL;DRWhile the game is cool enough to recommend, the bug killed it for me.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Don't judge this review by my time in steam, I've played alot in non-steam version.The story is enjoyable albeit not one of the best stories out there.Combat is pretty fluid.I like the setting and the crisp graphics for it's time, even now it looks really appealing in my opinion.The idea of having limited gold and potions is great, you always have to be on the lookout for the gold and potions in levels and not chug countless potions while having unlimited gold, alot of games that are like that are easy.This game isn't the most difficult either  but it isn't too easy... the difficulty is just right. I played this game in my childhood and never knew that people had kinda mixed thoughs about it (More positive thoughts  than negative which is nice).The game is also really atmospheric.There are some bad points in the game -Paladin is probably the most useful in the Light side and the others are kinda just there, the Dark side is more balanced.Alot of the Negative reviews are outdated, the game no longer pops up any ads for Raven's Cry so you can enjoy it without ads.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Enclave is a Real under rated Hack n Slash RPG Gem... I played it on the XBOX A Long Time Ago and after configuring the controls to my liking and setting the graphic to 1080P... I am totally digging it....It has a neat 1st person 3rd person camera switch that makes your shield, Sword, Bow transparent in 1st person mode..... its one of the little things that make this game different. Some have reported an adware in the game but I havent seen any of that. The game Runs Great and with it on sale less than a Dollar its a steal. As you collect gold in the levels you buy better gear and you can replay the levels after you complete them with any unlocked character to look for the missed gold. There are both light and dark campaigns to unlock 2 hidden characters not seen in the campaign and there is a config hack to unlock console commands but it is reccommended to back up your save before you try it. Also a level editor exists for the game, which has been updated if you look for it... I really wish the MOD community gave this game some Love....Do yourself a favor and add it to your collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												An old school action-adventure game.  It's old, so don't expect anything ground breaking.  Premade characters with premade fighting styles that get upgrades as you progress through the story & earn money.  The combat is hack/slash with different styles between which character you choose to play.  There are archers & mages which play like a 1st/3rd person shooter of sorts.  Just make sure you have mana before starting fights.  Enemies don't have much variation between them.  You'll encounter the same types throughout every level with them getting harder & more armored as you progress.STORYThere isn't really a good story here.  It's mostly about you being in a war & your leader telling you to go do stuff.  There are good & evil stories to play through but you can't play the villain story until you beat the good one which is a bummer.GRAPHICSDon't expect much visually since it's an older game.  It's not bad looking but everything does look brown/grey.  Like they were going for a more realistic tone.  It's pretty bland & boring overall.  The character models look good at least.AUDIONothing major here either.  The game does have basic 3D surround sound, but I'm not sure how it is since I don't have a setup for it.  Music is generic & loops through the levels.  Voice acting is good & tolerable.  Sound effects are basic explosions, clangs, footsteps, etc.  Nothing super impressive.UIThere is no map in this game, but levels aren't that big so you won't really get lost.  Before each mission you equip your character with weapons & armor. You choose the missions to play via a world map.  Each mission is repeatable but you can't earn bonus gold from replaying each mission unless you earn more gold than you did in your previous playthrough.  Depending on how much gold you've earned you can equip yourself with better items & more potions.  You don't really "BUY/SELL" stuff in this game.  You find gold throughout the levels & it adds to your total gold pool.  The higher your gold pool the more you can equip.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay changes depending on the classes & there are 3 class types.  Warrior, Archer, & Mage.   You start with the warrior & unlock the rest as you play the game.  You unlock different versions of each as you progress as well.WARRIORS  The combat can get cumbersome for warriors.  You'll need to be constantly moving & attacking to avoid being hit & to get around some enemies defenses.  The Warrior is tall & a lot of your enemies are short so you'll keep swinging over their heads from time to time. He also often swings at an odd angle so even if the enemy isn't short you'll still miss.  You can use shields to block arrows & attacks, just make sure they hit the shield or you'll take damage.ARCHERS  They play pretty much like you'd expect.  You have to draw & time your shots.  Headshots do 10x bonus damage & are pretty much instant kills.  You get a variety of arrows like fire, explosive & sniper arrows.  Gameplay is slightly different depending on what bow you use.  You pretty much need to headshot enemies & that's easier said than done.  Each shot has a delay as well.MAGES  Mages equip staves & shoot things similar to the archers except they are more versatile. Each attack uses mana & their playstyle changes depending on which staff you're using.  The 1st staff is the most balanced.  A slow attack with a wide berth to give you room for errors.  The 2nd staff requires much more precision & is similar to using a bow without needing to draw an arrow.  The 3rd staff poisons your enemies & allows you to damage them over time.  Some enemies are immune/weak to certain staves so it's best to bring 2 staves with you if you can afford it.OVERALLThe game is monotanous & poorly designed.  The enemy AI is terrible & goes from being completely stupid to jump around & avoid all your attacks while they bash your face in.  If you play a ranged character you're gonna have a hard time because the enemies are constantly moving & have tiny heads and you NEED to headshot them in order to kill them.  If you play a melee character you're gonna have an even worse time because every enemy is so small your swings will always go over them or he'll just swing at wierd angles so if the enemy isn't short you'll miss anyways.  The levels are really linear as well.  It's pretty much a straight line, with one offshoot that unlocks if you can save someone from dying & some dead ends that hide more gold.  Enemies also spawn out of no where.  You'll often walk through an area with no enemies only to have them spawn behind you.The games not unplayable, but it is frustrating.  I'd not recommend it unless you get it on a good sale.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												It's alright, haven't seen any major bugs, combat tends to be a bit finicky but it's pretty good, sometimes the shield feels useless buuut you always get proven wrong, the game can be very very challenging at times, take mission 3 for example. mean ♥♥♥♥ those necromancers, I wound up using god mode after a bit because the game was getting to harsh and I just wanted to have fun and I can easily see how much more difficult it can get.One thing I like however is your gold collection is shared between your races/classes which is quite nice, like you can power through the first like, I unno, 6 or 7 missions as aKnight then you'll have enough gold to instantly kit out a Druid, I have noticed that in certain stages other classes do much better, take that fire level for example, where you get that frost blade, doing that on a druid is difficult, those little fire golems are like 96% resistant to your attacks.Would be cool to have achivements tho, in regards to cheating it's very limited and all you really have is God Mode and Finish Mission, that's it.Graphically and mechanically I'd say it's fairly decent for the time it was made, the voice acting in-game (not cutscenes) is pretty weird but eh, sub titles help alot.The price seems to be spot on for a game such as this, I recomend it if you want a decent medieval game with some nostalgia, I deffinately recomend getting it while it's on sale, it's pretty fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Its a hack and slash game, so there is not a whole lot to expect.You run around and hack and slash yourself through the enemies. There is a bunch of hidden treasures and even some maps that give you access to hidden levels. You collect gold in each level and in between you can buy better armor/weapons more motions etc. You unlock a bunch of different characters, that repeat themself not only in the form of being the same characters with different looks for both the dark and light campaign, but also by getting, lets say a sworsman in level 1 and in level 10 you can play the knight, that is the swordsman with more life and attack. so why bother with the swordsman? The classes therefor are basically: archer, mage, swordguy, something wird with bombs (never used that guy). The gold part is very interesting by the way. If you have, lets say 1000 gold and you get an armor for 500 and a sword for 200 then you still have 300 for potions or whatever. BUT: if you unequip the armor you get those full 500 back. This means you have a certain amount of gold, with which you can work and which equips whatever you want. Its seperate for each character as well. So you can use those 1000 gold to equip your archer and if you feel like playing mage instead you can use those 1000 gold no matter what your archer has equipped. The graphics are old but they dont hurt the eye or anything. The story is meh, but its about hacking and slashing not questing. you have small levels which you go through one after another and except for hidden treasures and levels there is not a whole lot else to do than to fight yourself through these levels. There is two more things you need to know: 1 Its brutally hard. Even on easy mode you will die often. Why is this a problem? Because if you die you have to restart the entire mission, unless you found a checkpoint. if you got one of those you only lose 5 gold if you die and restart from there. the monsters you have slain even after reaching the checkpoint stay dead. what else makes it hard? terrible hit detection. I played through the entire game light and dark campaign and I have no clue whatsoever as to when something counts as hit and when it doesnt. I smash my enemy 15 times and they dont take a scratch, I hit somewhere completely else and they get damage? Same goes for me, believing that hiding behind my shild will block the enemy hit. What a foolish thought.Fazit and TL:DR:Its mindless fun. See the enemy, kill the enemy, plunder the gold floating around everywhere and slay more enemys. And die a lot of times meanwhile.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Enclave is an old 2002 game which brought to steam in 2003, exactly 12 years before i played this game.The game itself is about medieval-style hack and slash game with a great graphic (from 2002 timeline perspective).I tried to like this game but.... somehow i felt something missing from the game while playing it, something that should be exist in game, enjoyment.I know it's subjective matter about enjoyment, but even an old game like Crash Team Racing can give me enjoyment while playing it better than this game.So here are the pros and cons of the game :Pros :+ Great and enticing graphic from 2002 game+ Nice UI game+ Smooth even in low spec PC (why can't this implemented in any other games? Dev?)+ Many weapons and armors choicesCons :- THE STORY, it's so bland and so obvious. Something that makes this game can't meet its expectation- Unresponsive control and stiff movements- Combat system and movement is so dull from 3D perspective. Should make it 2D side scrolling instead- Not too intelligent Artificial Intelligent (AI)- still too expensive for and old game (subjective but i got it free from friends lol)Still, i can't recommend this game for who seeks a great story based hack-and-slash game (because the game itself is trying to be one).But i if you don't mind about the bland and so-so story, you can try this game.4/10 because bland story and dull combat movement.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I don't set my bar very high when I buy an obscure fantasy game for under $5 bucks. The odd unexpected gem, occasional clever art design, or just experiencing the personal projects of earnest developers. Enclave is none of those. I've only played through maybe the first third of the Light campaign (there's an entire second one that you need to unlock), but my patience is officially dried up.The game starts with a lengthy cutscene that could have just as easily been titled "How Not to Write a Fantasy Story 101," opening up a quasi-mystical looking tome while a bored-sounding woman rambles on about the setting's origin story, throwing in some made-up fantasy words like "Dreg'atar" every third word in a deseperate effort to alienate the audience before the game even starts. (Tip for writers: foreign-sounding words are the deep end of the pool. The bigger the plot point the less likely you want to have to pull out a glossary to understand it.)Once the game starts it's a pretty bog-standard sloppy hack-and-slasher, paving through orcs and goblins because of course you are. Survival can get pretty finnicky as the clunky combat controls make tapdancing around your opponent the best means of defense, and occasionally an unpredictable exploding setpiece can kick you back to the start of the level. Still, not something I lost sleep over seeing as how it cost less than a dollar.The quality just sort of slowly slides downhill from there. Ranged attacks are borderline useless as they require extreme precision, which in a game where no one ever sits still and your rate of fire is roughly the same as horse droppings, means that at mid-ranges you'll miss, at close ranges you'll miss and get stabbed, and at long ranges you might hit and give your target a small papercut.Basically every level introduces a new class to play as, most of which are slight variations on your standard sword/shield/crossbow Knight that you started with. The most distinct one (that I've unlocked, anyway) is the Druid, who takes any semblance of class balance and crushes it between her gratuitously exposed thighs (you can unlock armor with pauldrons, but not pants. How does that make sense?). Her most basic staff summons spectral ravens that home in on their target and has a secondary power to summon an elemental as a disposable meatshield, and her mana restores so fast it basically serves only to slightly limit your rate of fire.Now if this were a sensibly balanced game, the average class would be able to plow through levels with moderate difficutly and the hilariously overpowered Druid would just sort of wander through spamming magic like you snuck Starkiller into a game of Star Wars Battlefront. But this isn't a sensibly balanced game, and the clumsy controls will have your melee characters limping with no potions inside of five minutes, basically giving you the options of "play Druid or get really familiar with the first room of each level."My patients burned up around level seven, which seemed easy enough like all the rest: wander around murdering ugly green people, grab loot, find exit. Unfortunately, the level is also littered with archer assassins, who use the same burst arrows as your Huntress class, but with unlimited ammo and impeccable aim. They can, and will, take you from full health to dead in one shot before you can even make out their silhouette through the game's heavy fog, and in a game where each level has MAYBE two checkpoints, there's only so many times I can try and play Russian Roulette with trying to snipe them through the fog before I give up and chuck the game in the trash.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Good, solid action-RPGStory: 18/25 Gameplay: 16/25 Graphics: 20/25 Sound: 15/25OVERALL: 69/100Enclave is just a good old game, and like many old games, suffers from being an old game. The story was good but not at all memorable and I felt the dark campaign's story was way more intriguing than the light campaign's. The gameplay is a bit all over the place, some levels are hard, some easy. Some classes are overpowered, some useless. It also suffers from occasionally poor hit detection. The graphics are pretty decent for the age and there is a wide variety of locales, but they seem really bland after a while. The the sound is fair but repetitive and the grunts got annoying very quickly. I would get on sale or in a bundle.Final Note: The Dark Campaign, just ... why, it gets so stupidly hard. Hard in the "unfair" and not the "difficult" aspect of hard.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This isn't an RPG at all,  its a typical hack and slash action game.  There has barely any loot accept gold and health pots and very rarely a particular level will reward you with an upgraded item for the various characters you'll unlock as you progress.  The combat is a mess with button bashing the par for the game, blocking serves limited purpose as you'll be wildly swinging your weapon around hoping for actual contact with enemies, sometimes it doesn't even register.The defence Enclave has is its age, its quite old now - but even so, back in 2003 there was RPGS around that did a better job in the third person action rpg genre.   Levels are all extremely linear in nature, and some areas are quite confusing and its easy to get lost and frustrated.Graphics wise, its above par considering its age - this is probably why it got so many positive reviews.  But in terms of actual gameplay, its sub-par and the difficulty increases quite rapidly to a point you'll rage over cheap deaths from traps or other stupid game mechanics.

The Look*If you have a fetish for graphic then is maybe not for you because is from year 2003+Turn up the setting if you want *Never played "Gothic 1" but the properties are similar: medieval, third-person-view*You start as Knight and can playing as that for each other ChapterSome facts+More Classes get unlocked and each Chapter is aviable to repeat*You can colect coins; Health potion (medicine in a bottle); hidden ammo (unless you using melee-weapons or magic)*If you respawn from a Checkpoint- you don't win back your ammo (important as Hunter). Just repeat the Chapter than*Amazing Menu with that Crow*Because is from year 2003 they don't have Game-Pad support/option (Could be a good "Play Station 2" title)Summary10/10. Perfect mechanism with a big world in Chapters (and with funny glitches)

												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.Eat.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I first played this game on the original Xbox and I beat it many times, but I was honestly sad that it wasn't compatible on the Xbox 360. Our original Xbox works great so I can play Enclave on it again, but I found this game on steam long before we got the console repaired. The checkpoint system makes the game a little easier to play for rookie players, and the removal of the lock-on circles equalizes the use of all ranged weapons and staves. And the difficulty settings are cool too for a classic game. Honestly I was ok with the original game with the lock-on circles, no checkpoints (except for Durzu and Mordessa in the Light Campaign), and no separate difficulty settings. However, I was so excited to see this game again and I just love to be able to experience part of the very beginning of my teen years once again. I just play on the Hard difficulty so I can avoid having the checkpoints, and the game is easy enough to beat anyways. I woud recommend this game because its very simple and straight forward, but it can be also challenging as well because I have still not been able to perfect all characters for all levels just yet. Graphics were excellent back when it was released and the gameplay was just fine back then too. So anyone complaing about the graphics and gameplay can just shut go back to their overdone next gen games because this is my favorite all time game.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #56 - EnclaveI'll start with the good, since it won't take me very long.  The graphics are really nice considering this game came out in 2003.  I also enjoyed the music.  A little less impressive is the level design.  I did like the way the game encourages exploration to find hidden gold.  But the levels are very linear.  There's definitely nothing open world about Enclave.I didn't play long enough to get a good sense of the story.  But the main character seems to be the "silent protagonist", which personally I am not a fan of, but sometimes it can work.  Other characters do talk however, and I found the voice acting to be somewhat uneven.  Some of it was good, and some of it sounded like they asked someone in QA to fill in for a day.Also, you might notice the game is tagged as "RPG", but don't make the mistake of thinking it is one, because it's really not.  It's more of an action adventure game in a fantasy setting.  But it lacks many of the things you'd expect in a typical RPG, like an inventory screen, or character customization, or skills or stats, or a map of some kind.For a game that focuses on action, I wished the actual action was a little better.  Combat just seemed to be your basic button mashing.  There is some variety in the sense that you can change weapons and use a ranged weapon instead of a melee weapon, and the weapons can have different speeds.   But that's about it for the variety, and mostly I found myself just mashing the attack button.Speaking of the mouse button, I found myself wishing the game supported a controller, but it doesn't.  Another annoyance I found is, even though the game uses keyboard and mouse, from the main menu the mouse doesn't work, so you have to navigate solely with the keyboard, which made the initital setup and configuration annoying.It's a shame that the developers didn't put a little more work into the gameplay, instead of just making the game pretty.  Perhaps if I had reviewed this in 2003 I would have been a little kinder.  But even so, there were far better RPGs to play even back then.  What little is good about this game is outweighed by the bland combat and gameplay, and other annoyances like having to skip credits when you quit, which for me it's been the last time.  Don't even need to finish my hour on this one.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												This isn't an RPG at all, its a typical hack and slash action game. There has barely any loot accept gold and health pots and very rarely a particular level will reward you with an upgraded item for the various characters you'll unlock as you progress. The combat is a mess with button bashing the par for the game, blocking serves limited purpose as you'll be wildly swinging your weapon around hoping for actual contact with enemies, sometimes it doesn't even register.The defence Enclave has is its age, its quite old now - but even so, back in 2003 there was RPGS around that did a better job in the third person action rpg genre. Levels are all extremely linear in nature, and some areas are quite confusing and its easy to get lost and frustrated.Graphics wise, its above par considering its age - this is probably why it got so many positive reviews. But in terms of actual gameplay, its sub-par and the difficulty increases quite rapidly to a point you'll rage over cheap deaths from traps or other stupid game mechanics.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This game is neither a rpg or a beat 'n' up. You have to complete quests and every quest is a complete level. There's no open world, there is only one possible way to go on. In every level you can find hidden gold which you need to buy armor, weapons and healing potions before you start a level/quest and you unlock new characters. And that's it. No level ups, no experience and no inventory. Before a quest starts you just choose a character like a warrior, mage or archer and buy him equippment. There's no a big difference between the weapons and armor, it's just like: pay more gold and it do more damage. Once a quest started you run with your character through a scripted tube-level and kill everything you meet. Sounds like fun, but the fighting-system is bad. I just played as warrior and he could only attack. If you equip a shield you can block, but there aren't special abilities or something similar. The fighting system is comparabel with the fighting system from Oblivion, but without magic. This game will disappoint you if you want a rpg with focus on confrontations, because this game isn't really a rpg and the fighting-system is bad. But if you want to run through scripted levels and kill everthing by useing only two buttons, this game could be entertaining.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This game is neither a rpg or a beat 'n' up. You have to complete quests and every quest is a complete level. There's no open world, there is only one possible way to go on. In every level you can find hidden gold which you need to buy armor, weapons and healing potions before you start a level/quest and you unlock new characters. And that's it. No level ups, no experience and no inventory. Before a quest starts you just choose a character like a warrior, mage or archer and buy him equippment. There's no a big difference between the weapons and armor, it's just like: pay more gold and it do more damage. Once a quest started you run with your character through a scripted tube-level and kill everything you meet. Sounds like fun, but the fighting-system is bad. I just played as warrior and he could only attack. If you equip a shield you can block, but there aren't special abilities or something similar. The fighting system is comparabel with the fighting system from Oblivion, but without magic. This game will disappoint you if you want a rpg with focus on confrontations, because this game isn't really a rpg and the fighting-system is bad. But if you want to run through scripted levels and kill everthing by useing only two buttons, this game could be entertaining.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												The basic premise of the game is to go around various dungeons, kill stuff, collect gold to buy items and do the next dungeon.  I really wouldnt consider this a RPG, as there is no real role play, its an action game, and a pretty decent one at that.The story is simple;  bad guys coming to kill you.. kill them before they can kill you.  And the dark campaign is basically the same, except youre the baddy. Its pretty for its age, it has some nice environments and nicely done mechanics. A good example of these mechanics would be the halfling lady. Shes too short to be hit with certain  attacks, so shes good when facing certain enemies.  I know this may sound broken, but its pretty obvious its intentional. Enclave is a game that has a refreshing level of difficulty as well. If you die, and dont have a checkpoint, you restart from the beginning. If you do have a checkpoint activated, it costs 10 gold to bring you back. I never died enough to lose all of my money so I dont know what happens then.  Alot of the complaints about the difficulty are from people who did not get far enough in to get the checkpoints. Really the only issues I had with the game, is that its rather short, and linear, and the fact that its labeled an RPG when it barely has RPG elements to it. Its an action game 100%. That being said its worth it, especially if its on sale!

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Enclave is an ARPG that has gone terribly wrong. The "action" portion of this game is a joke, completely mundane and extremely repetitive. If you are a melee character all you do is hold down the mouse to swing your weapon like a mad man (and your attacks will randomly hit or miss), and if you're a ranged character you can shoot enemies from range since the AI is not smart enough to detect you. While attacking you can just keep dancing around your enemies and they have nothing to answer your dance. Furthermore, there is no skill tree or any character customization besides equipping your character with different items at the start of each mission. That's right, there is no continuous character with quests, instead you get a mission selection screen where you can pick a specific character and choose your loadout. You can purchase different items by finding gold, which are all scattered throughout the levels making you run around looking for bags of gold instead of focusing on the action and the combat. Lastly, the story is nothing special and is your generic save our kingdom for the bad guys - easily forgettable. Luckily I was able to get this game for free, and I do not recommend anyone picking this one up when there are much better ARPGs out there!

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Enclave is a gem of a game from the original X-Box era back in 2003. Its a third or first person medieval fantasy hack and slash with engaging combat and exceptional environments. For the rogue in all us there is a dark campaign where you play as several evil classes like assassin, berserker, lich and sorceress to name a few. If there are any good hearts out there, you also have the light campaign with their human counterpart classes such as knight, huntress, druid, wizard and half-ling. Each campaign lasted me a fun and joyous seven hours. At the start of each level you select your class and assign their equipment from the money you have. Nothing is permanently bought, so if you want expensive armor and a weak weapon with a few potions, you can do it or if zero potions, expensive weapons and armor is more to your liking go for it. The money is never spent, just assigned. These classes, play styles and different equipment go a long way to making each play through different, even if its your twentieth time on a level.

												I have to say... this is really bad. First of all you have exactly one attack. No block, no roll, etc. Just wildly spamming left mouse. Second, this is easy on the hardest mode. Third, this is a TERRIBLE console port. You can't even navigate the menu with your mouse... that's how lazy they were. No real graphics improvements either. Ironically you can't use a controller to play either. They did not make the gold fun to find either, its always just hiding behind the rock you are passing or stairs you are going up. And the saving is automatic at start of level with no checkpoints in between, meaning if you fell off a thin flight of stairs or something, you are stuck repeating the level.
