content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I had high expectations. Maby too high expectations. I regret buying this game on so many levels. I have only played the first 15 minutes of this game. My first complaint is that the game is very glitchy. What I mean is that, I can't walk in a straight line because the game keeps teleporting me either in front of me or behind me. This is beyond annoying. My second major problem with the game is how clunky the gameplay is - it takes almost too long to swing a ♥♥♥♥ing sword and the AI is terrible. The voices of the characters is also very annoying and bad. This may be possibly the WORST game I have ever played on Steam. I am very dissapointed that I just wasted $5 on a game that I thought would be like Fable - an MMO, RPG (which what it was casted under) that I thought I could enjoy. The game starts off terrible too, you start off in a jail cell with an insane lady threatening to kill you. Then you get shot at with a giant catapult (the game is set in olden ages) and you have to escape through a hole. I won't spoil the rest. I get that this game was made awhile ago, but the game looks absolutely terrible. Even with all of the textures and normal video settings, the game looks terrible. I must also remind that the developers had absolutely no idea on what resolutions were. My moniter has a resolution of 1440x900 and when I switched to it, it gave me a resolution of 800x600 in a letterbox style. This was absolutely annoying to have to go through and find a decient resolution that didn't look half as bad. I could go on all day about how BAD this game was. Please, please, please don't waste your money on this game! 2/10

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
Product received for free
												Short version: this game is bad, don’t play it.Slightly longer version:  Do not buy this game, do not play this game.  The whole thing is clunky and awkward.  The animations for everything are awful.  The textures look like they belong in an edgy version of the original fable, and I don’t mean that in a good way (if you even think there is a good way to interpret that).  The combat is worse than many free to play rpgs.  The characters (to the point where I couldn’t take it anymore) were uninteresting.  The combat consisted of A. sniping enemies with ranged attacks and never fighting anything, or B. running forward at the enemy and left clicking.  There are many free to play games of much higher quality than this, play anything else.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Tried to play this game, sadly it keeps bugging out at start-up. It kept flickering and stuttering, even fast-forwarding through the menus so much that I couldn't even start the game. I spent a few hours online looking for a fix, and saw that this was a common problem for PC's with multiple cores (which is pretty much all of them these days).I tried reconfiguring the config files, setting admin start, even setting the affinity to one processor core, but nothing worked. Sadly this game seems to be one of the older games Steam sells that just won't run.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I have never played a worst game in my entire 21 years on this beautiful space rock. To subject yourself to the absolute depressing abyss that is Enclave is equal to being thrown into a psychotic blind rage and killing everyone on earth. Afterwards coming to your senses in a field full of their cold corpses, having built a small hut in the middle of it and adorned it with their entrails and various bits of clothing.To even be subconsciously aware that this title exists is pure and visceral pain that I cannot repress. All ye who enter here abandon hope.

number of helpful: 5 of 17 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												If not for the horrible combat this would be a good game from 2003. But the combat has some of the worst hit detection I have ever seen in a game in my life. It does not matter if you can see your sword blade hitting the enemy. You wont hit it unless an enemy is directly in front of you, and I mean DIRECTLY in a very thin line hit box, and you are so close to it you are touching it. The combat is laughably bad anyway. Just really generic and has no substance at all. The combat is so laughably generic I kept laughing at how it just feels like the very baasic 0's and 1's binary code for an atari game. The ONE THING this game has going for it is that amazingly for a game from 2003 it has vsync and supports 1920x1080. Blows my mind a game that old supports that res unless it was updated since 2003. It also installed and played fine with no technical issues at all, unless you count the fact that the game sucks balls as a technical issue, which I do. If the game sucks so bad you can't stand to play it, that is a stand out technical issue.3/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 15 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Not horrible, but poorly made. You get more characters as the game goes on that carry different gear, otherwise they are all the same. There is no leveling, just new gear.  The new gear isn't always better, just more expenive.  There's no stats on any of the gear, just guess.  It is hard to hit targets, as they jump around like some kind of multi-player game.  Your jump however is very limited and painful to get on a box or jump a hole that will kill you.  Jumping looks very awkward, and is also required in every level of the game.  The melee fighting sucks the most, just use a crossbow or a staff. The story is stupid, just skip that and play. You basically get thrown into fighting and collecting money, without teaching you how to do much. Traps will kill you, and appear without reason, so use your psycic ability(not real).  There are checkpoints, costs money to revive, unless you haven't found one, then restart map. So it's a cheaply made game, bugs won't get fixed, it's too old.  It's not worth more than $1, and only if you're really bored.

number of helpful: 14 of 37 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A very cheap linear pseudo-RPG. You play a guy, run him through a level, collect coins and stuff and unlock Characters. Starting the next Level you can select a Character, its equipment and give him/her potions, etc..This could be a very fun game but the combat system is worse than the graphics look, which for a game like this is very bad. I'm not very far in, but that is because the game isn't really engaging either! Also would the one factor to return be that it's some good brainless fun - but that would require the combat system to be  entertaining. It is, if you're cynical though. The "coins" (money bags) are hidden so cheaply within all in all very badly designed Levels that it doesn't feel like an achievement at the end of the Level and doesn't really add a lot of replay value because that would require one to play a Level again! Yes - as bad as that!You need to be desperate to play this game, then you may enjoy it for a while.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The Good:- Great visuals for a game released in 2002- Good soundtrack (works well enough for the fantasy themes...)The Bad:- The combat system is pure garbage. Really bad hit detection thrown in with cheap enemies who seem to strike masses of damage while you struggle to even land a decent blow. - Enemy AI is crap (but it often helps me when they jump to their deaths...)- Storyline and voice acting is medicore. - No RPG systems in place whatsoever. Purely gear based (which is not a bad thing), but I am not convinced on its overall execution, as the game's emphasis on combat just doesnt come across as fun. The Verdict - A Polished Turd.Visuals and sound aside, I found little to actually enjoy from the gameplay. If you like this style of this game, go and play Risen, Gothic or Two Worlds instead... They are superior titles.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Overall it's a very good game both graphically and gameplay wise. Though, if i had to say one thing bad about it, It would have to be along the lines of it lagging and speeding up randomly through the game making the casm clearing jumps very, very difficult. (My computer more than exceeds minimum and recommended specs) That would be my only complaint about the game. In every other aspect of the game you will be stunned at what you find. This game both looks beautiful (given the age of its graphics), sounds amazing, have much diversity with play (both how you play and what you play with character and weapon wise), and above all is it is cheap and easy to get a system to run it. I most definitly recommend this game to anyone that has $5 they want to spend on a game. I enjoy it and I wish for everyone else to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Dont buy this♥♥♥♥♥♥unless from nostalgic reasons, I have never played this game before I bought it on steam:Pros:+ different classes+ coins collectibles makes exploring worthwhile (but this applies only for some people)+ relatively long gameplay (20+ hours I would say for most poeple, but I am doing all coins which sometimes require 3x - 4x restart because of cheap deaths - to collect all coins you must no die a single time)+ changing enviroment (mission from mission)Cons:- terrible camera, I have been in game for 5 minutes in 1st mission and already hated it- RPG? Where? Just get the best equipment and gogogo- actual combat, the worst meele combat I have chance to witnessed, the worst part of it - you are swinging your weapon against enemy and nothing happens unless you are very specifically turned towards your enemy, even though it looks like you should be hitting all enemies in radius of 90+ degrees (graphics) the reality is about from 30 - 40, for me the most frustrating part of this game- cheap deaths (applies for gold collectors only, fall into lava, pit etc., you just must restart whole level if you want 100% of gold coins)- AI - shooting with a crossbow/bow in this game is absolutely delightful (sarcasm) - AI jumps like mad (seriously you must see it to understand) and it is almost impossible, also stucks behind objects sometimes cant even follow you upstairs etc..Result: Mediocre, but those frustrating parts I have written down (camera, combat system...) will follow you throughout this whole game therefore -> not worth it (I have bought it for 0.99 Eur, so for this price it is decent)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Classic and fun action game, yes as many have said this isnt really an RPG, its an action platform game and a good one. ( The genre tag was placed by users not the developer ) Its a solid action game with lots of combat and light platforming.                     The combat is loose ( not very precise ) but because hit detection is forgiving it makes combat fast and fun, and there is a good variety of weapons in the game to keep you interested. In fact variety is one of the games strengths, there are several characters you can play in the campaign and you can choose freely before every level which one you want to play and every character specializes in different weapons and attributes so they all are very different to play ( most have exclusive abilities. ) And the most unique part of the game, adding even more variety, is that there is a good and evil campaign and you can choose either one to play, this isnt just a gimmick either both campaigns have there very own story and levels. ( Each side has there own version of each class and character ) Speaking of those levels, level design is excellent. Levels are labrynth style with lots  of hidden gold to find and even if they are short they still provide exploration. Also the levels have a good amount going on with lots of scripted enviromental changes ( Such as falling walls and ceilings ) and props ( like shootable cannons ), the geometry is always changing from tight cordoors to wide open enviroments with lots of verticality such as muti-story buildings and archway bridges. Finally the enemy placement is great as well as you will be suprised often by enemies that hide around or rush around corners, down stairways, etc or how archers that nest up in high vantage points or off in the distance. Overall some good engaging level design.                 What also must be said is how good the game looks in 1080p concidering it is over 10 years old. Textures look great ( not quite as much if you get really close though ). Art design is amazing, all the architecture and details put into the enviroment surpass alot of games today and it has aged remarkably well, seriously what other game from 2002 looks this good today. The only gripe I have is that character models and animations are old and stiff, but still nothing too terrible.                 The game isnt perfect of coarse. A.I. can and will be dumb ( there are times that your enemy will just stand there and take hits especially if there are more than one enemy at a time ). The spending of gold is very strange as it is never actually expended but more a value of how much or with what a character is equiped with before they enter the level. Also the game only saves between levels and there are only a couple of checkpoint in level at most, if you die before you reach a checkpoint you will have to repeat everything you did in that level. The game has some balancing issues such as the sorceress character is overpowered as she is basically a machine gun spellcaster. But still this is a steal for 5$ and especially on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This game hasn't aged well. Admittedly, I didn't get very far into the game before stopping, but having hit a game-breaking bug quite quickly I couldn't be bothered to reload the level I was playing.The game is from 2003 according to the store page, and for a game of that time it actually looks fairly good. However, I found that whilst you could defend with a shield, most of your combat experience (at least as a "Knight") would involve furiously circle-strafing and mashing the LMB to hit the rather stupid AI opponents.The allied AI isn't much better. In the second mission I managed to lose a friendly AI that should have been following me, and in the third mission, the AI and the scenery bugged out, causing the AI I was escorting to get fatally stuck on a door.Finally, the vast majority of the story (from what I could tell) was relayed through skippable cutscenes, making it all to easy to lose track of what was going on. There was no obvious way to receive cues on the story whilst in the game itself either, making it quite hard to follow.Overall, the experience was somewhat frustrating, and I'd give this game a miss.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I picked this game up off steam for 59p using the left over change in my wallet. i bought it thniking it was going to be one of those poorly made, cheap, crappy games you see lying at the bottom of the store, i was wrong. This game is fun, good looking, and runs great. The game features a wide range of linear missions to choose from including survival mode. each map has verious secrets and hidden places where you can find secret pickups to help aid you. You will spend most of your time exploring the wide path. The game also offers a fair amount of customisation. Their are multiple characters you can choose from, each having thier own abilities. Using the money you collected in the previous missions, you can buy new weapons such as hammers, swords, maces, axes, bows, crossbows. You can also buy new shields, armor and other equipment such as health and other items that you come across in the game. the gameplay is great but aiming the ranged weapons could use some improvement. The game also offers a good challenge. the game can also get very difficult from time to time. The checkpoints are also kind of spaced out too far though, with some mission being around 30-45 minuites long, only one checkpoint is usually placed in that map, making it very fustrating if you die. Overall i'm impressed, however, very rarely, the game just instantly closes and quits to the desktop without me doing annything, that can also be very fustrating as the game does not save during missions. This game is aging well, it runs well on my high end PC and my cheap, low end laptop. Besides that bug, this game is great, its not perfect, but at least its fun. Should you pick it up? for under £4, yes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Bought this game at a cut price; such a classic style Action RPG. Great combat, solid controls which are easy to learn and remember. Haven't got a controller to work with it yet, but with programs like XPadder, I don't see why it would be difficult; not necessary, but it shouldn't be too hard if you really dislike keyboard and mouse.The only downside is the low graphical quality; which is understandable when you consider the 2003 release date. Character models are pretty good for the age, but landscape textures are very blurred. Resolution goes up to 1080p, which is awesome, and for a port, the options menu is pretty detailed.I probably wouldn't recommend you buy this game at £3.99, since the game is so old now, that just sounds unnecessarily high. Like I said, I bought this in a sale and it cost me £1.

content:

												This game is quite old, and yes, it crashes sometimes (Actually now seems fixed by removing v sync) frame rate is embarassing same is the camera angle, but still I think the game itself is quite enjoyable: Many characters to play with, many weapons, 2 different campaigns.The graphics are not that bad for a game of more than 10 years ago, and some effects and plot twists are almost surprising.It has even the right level of difficulty. In particular, it is damn hard to find all the coins in all levels, but doing so is unsuitable and annoying 'cause of backtracking.I am actually enjoying playing it again after so much time. 												I read weird reviews about how the game tries to make pop-up ads come on, but as I saw myself and as someone else who I saw reviewd this game, it doesn't do that anymore. I don't even know why that's a big deal in the first place. Anyway, this game was kind of fun. It had its moments and it was surprisingly difficult. It suffered from a lot of gameplay and level design issues. At times the game mechancis made the experience frustrating, although in the end the hardest levels were not impossible, but required immense precision and determination in order to overcome the questionable gaming mechanics and level design. Like some other people said before; collecting gold is KEY. It's the only way to have good equipment in the game. Thankfully you can replay levels to collect more gold in order to have better equipment before moving on to the next level. Ther are 14 missions and I missed like 2000 gold, but I was able to get the best equipment for each character. Anyway, it's a good time waster if you wait for it to be on 95% off, like I did. Otherwise I don't think it's worth 4.99.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I picked this game up off steam for 59p using the left over change in my wallet. i bought it thniking it was going to be one of those poorly made, cheap, crappy games you see lying at the bottom of the store, i was wrong. This game is fun, good looking, and runs great. The game features a wide range of linear missions to choose from including survival mode. each map has verious secrets and hidden places where you can find secret pickups to help aid you. You will spend most of your time exploring the wide path. The game also offers a fair amount of customisation. Their are multiple characters you can choose from, each having thier own abilities. Using the money you collected in the previous missions, you can buy new weapons such as hammers, swords, maces, axes, bows, crossbows. You can also buy new shields, armor and other equipment such as health and other items that you come across in the game. the gameplay is great but aiming the ranged weapons could use some improvement. The game also offers a good challenge. the game can also get very difficult from time to time. The checkpoints are also kind of spaced out too far though, with some mission being around 30-45 minuites long, only one checkpoint is usually placed in that map, making it very fustrating if you die. Overall i'm impressed, however, very rarely, the game just instantly closes and quits to the desktop without me doing annything, that can also be very fustrating as the game does not save during missions. This game is aging well, it runs well on my high end PC and my cheap, low end laptop. Besides that bug, this game is great, its not perfect, but at least its fun. Should you pick it up? for under £4, yes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												Another of my childhood classics. I played this alot more than Steam says due to the fact that I got it a long time ago thanks to a gaming magazine. This is a great example of a game that passed the test of time: both the graphics and the gameplay are amazing even by today`s standards.The combat is the meat of this game and everything blends in nicely. The weapons are AMAZING...swinging a giant orcish axe never felt so satisfying and being a stealthy assassin is just amazing due to the multitude of tools available (all the arrow types remind me of the Thief series). This game also has one of my all time favourite levels in video game history: the haunted mansion. Evading all the traps in that place was just amazing.There is not much more I could say about this game other than the fact that it`s a must have for all lovers of classic old games. If I`d use a raing system this would get a perfect 10 out of 10.

												I finished this game last night, and i certainly dont understand all the bad rep this game got when i got it.The game is very good, you hack and slash through the level and collect coin bags and gems stashed and hidden throughout the map to add funds to your "campaign" after a few levels you start getting more characters to use who can also benefit from those war funds.You can buy your characters weapons, shields, crossbows, bolts (for the crossbow), bows, arrows (i'll let you guess for what), oil flasks, bombs, magic staves, and armor. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Nice graphics for the time,♥♥♥♥♥♥gameplay for the ages.For it's era it has nice graphics and they knew that. They push the graphics all over your face. Every menu transition has overly elaborate and unnecessary transition animations. But now that it is a decade later and the graphics have aged all of these are just tedious instead. The game is an obvious console showcase title, and I could tell this was originally a console game just from the menu screen without prior knowledge. It just feels like a console game.Music is nothing special, I forget all about it about in 5 seconds as soon as I quit the game.Story is non-existant. Sure there is a huge plot dump with cutscenes and inter-mission logs but it is entirely forgettable. It's the most generic Good vs Evil plot ever. NPCs have no character and neither does the guy you control for that matter. And speaking of the guy you control, you can actually control many different types of classes. They unlock one by one after completing the first few missions. It's rather pointless since they all unlock just a few missions in.So you can choose what class you want to play as and by choose I mean choose Druid or suffer. Why? Because combat sucks. Hit detection is terrible. Picking an archer might sound nice but it is not so nice when you realize it is impossibile to hit enemies yet enemy archers have perfect aim. Even melee sucks, you just go next to and enemy and mash attack and maybe hit one third of the time. Hit detection is down right broken.The only class that is worth playing is the Druid because she has a staff that can cast "homing magical bird missiles" and summon a golem to fight for you (although don't expect golem to do much, the AI is terrible). Even homing missiles don't hit all the time, they just circle around the enemy and dissipate but it is your only choice if you want to beat this game without losing your♥♥♥♥♥♥over the stupid combat.But even with the Druid and her gamebreaking weapon, the game is still boring. Because the way the game is designed is more like a corridor shooter than anything else. There are no side objectives and absolutely ZERO exploration. In fact it does that annoying thing where if you steer of the road, it counts down and fails your mission, all because you wanted to get out of the linear path and maybe go for a swim.Levels are short and all you have to do is get to the next objective. If your objective doesn't include killing enemies you can just ignore them and go the next waypoint and beat the mission. One guy wrote that this game had varied mission. Phwahaha, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game has only ONE mission: Get to the objective area and kill enemies in your path if they block you from getting to the objective area. Every single mission is this. Even escort missions are like this. I didn't even have to escort the guy I was suppose to protect, I just ignored him and went to the waypoint and he turned out fine.Don't waste your time on this one, there are so many other games to play.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!! It is a generic third person hack and slash that is only fun for the first level. Which only lasts about five minutes. To try and redeem itself the third level is... an escort mission. Escort missions are terrible, no one likes them, and this one is the worst. The merchant you have to protect takes insane amounts of damage from one enemy, and you are too far away to do anything about it because you move so slow. If you try to shoot at the enemy, good luck. All of the attacks only hit when they want to, and even then. The basic crossbow barely does any damage to the first enemies of the game.All in all. don't buy this game, even at 69 cents it's not worth anything close to that, and to think they are asking five dollars for the normal price is appalling. During the Christmas sale you can usually get Skyrim for seven dollars.Whatever you choose to do. Do not buy this game. It doesn't take much effort to figure out why this game is on sale for so little.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I don't know about the adware other people have been getting, as I haven't gotten it yet. So I will just point out that either the adware has been removed or I have a glitch, so the adware will not have an affect on my review.So, get this out of the way before the rest happens: The menu is ugly. However, that's the menu. In game, the graphics are good for a 12 year old game. Don't expect any nice landscapes, however. You're essentially closed in all the time, and everything is pretty linear.I got the game for free from somewhere. I noticed my friend had the game and asked him how good it was while it was downloading, and he said it was meh. When I got in, I played the first two missions, and thought it would get boring quickly as the only thing that was happening was I was running around with a sword and crossbow. I was hoping that wasn't it, but I uninstalled the game.I came back to the game today because I noticed it had trading cards and I figured I might as well play a bit and get some money. I played the first two missions, but noticed that when I finished the second mission I unlocked a new character called the huntress. I played with her. The only difference between them is instead of having a sword and shield she could have a bow and crossbow, however the knight could already have a crossbow and the huntress could have a dagger. While I was glad there was another character and was expecting more, the huntress really wasn't worth it. And up to this point, the combat has been pretty much the same. I played and unlocked a new character, the druid, which involves magic! She has 3 staffs, of which 2 are the same rapid fire and one is a charge up and summon. One of the rapid fire staves can poison but is very expensive (all equipment you take with you is limited by your money) and you can't either other staff, so it's better to go with the cheaper rapid fire and the summon. However, having the summon and rapid fire shot is interesting for gameplay, as it does mean there are different gameplay styles. The druid, while having massive damage, takes damage very quickly.I just finished playing and to my surprise- there was a boss! The boss can't exactly be damaged just by hitting it, but there is a different way you are supposed to do it. So the bosses aren't just dodge and hit, but they are more zelda style bosses. The only issue is that while fighting the boss there is no indication of wether or not you are actually doing anything until you do it quite a bit, and then he starts changing color so you know you're doing the right thing.I also unlocked the engineer, who seems like he'll have an interesting gameplay style as well!Overall, this game is quite fun. Worth $5? I would say so, as long as you're fine with not-so-amazing graphics (they are decent) and being mostly closed in all the time. If you want something better, an open world game might be more for you.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												I have to say... this is really bad. First of all you have exactly one attack. No block, no roll, etc. Just wildly spamming left mouse. Second, this is easy on the hardest mode. Third, this is a TERRIBLE console port. You can't even navigate the menu with your mouse... that's how lazy they were. No real graphics improvements either. Ironically you can't use a controller to play either. They did not make the gold fun to find either, its always just hiding behind the rock you are passing or stairs you are going up. And the saving is automatic at start of level with no checkpoints in between, meaning if you fell off a thin flight of stairs or something, you are stuck repeating the level.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Scripted within an ancient tome, which lies beneath centuries of dust in the guarded library of Meckalon, is the story of how I began playing this game.I grew up on this classic hack and slash, played it for years. If you're a fan of an engaging lore, descriptive graphics, cool weapons, even cooler characters, and smooth controls, then this game is for you. Yeah sure the graphics are extremely outdated but for a game made in the early 2000s its pretty good. There is an xbox version of this game but compared to that the controls on this PC version are a LOT easier to work with. I do like the walk feature on the xbox though. And you won't have to worry about having certain requirements with a game like this. I ran this on a Compaq Presario CQ62 late last year running Windows 7 on a 32-bit system, before switching to my current 64-bit Windows 8 Toshiba.And as someone who recently bought and played the game, I can confirm that the adware HAS been removed. However I've played this game for almost half an hour and I haven't received any trading cards yet.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												All right, Enclave is a very old game, more than 10 years old. But it's a good, old-school, sword-shield hack and slash game. You know, the story sucks, voice acting is meh, graphics are outdated. But that's not what counts. That old-school feeling back when we were playing crappy games (but they were their time's BEST of the best), that feeling of controls being a little clunky but somehow also familiar and nice, that feeling. That's what's in this game.Level design is good. The hitting/shooting/casting effects are satisfying. Story doesn't make sense, but like I said. Killing weird creatures with joy is what counts.It's $5 anyway. I would say it's worth for a couple days of nostalgia.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The Good:- Great visuals for a game released in 2002- Good soundtrack (works well enough for the fantasy themes...)The Bad:- The combat system is pure garbage. Really bad hit detection thrown in with cheap enemies who seem to strike masses of damage while you struggle to even land a decent blow. - Enemy AI is crap (but it often helps me when they jump to their deaths...)- Storyline and voice acting is medicore. - No RPG systems in place whatsoever. Purely gear based (which is not a bad thing), but I am not convinced on its overall execution, as the game's emphasis on combat just doesnt come across as fun. The Verdict - A Polished Turd.Visuals and sound aside, I found little to actually enjoy from the gameplay. If you like this style of this game, go and play Risen, Gothic or Two Worlds instead... They are superior titles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Nice graphics for the time,♥♥♥♥♥♥gameplay for the ages.For it's era it has nice graphics and they knew that. They push the graphics all over your face. Every menu transition has overly elaborate and unnecessary transition animations. But now that it is a decade later and the graphics have aged all of these are just tedious instead. The game is an obvious console showcase title, and I could tell this was originally a console game just from the menu screen without prior knowledge. It just feels like a console game.Music is nothing special, I forget all about it about in 5 seconds as soon as I quit the game.Story is non-existant. Sure there is a huge plot dump with cutscenes and inter-mission logs but it is entirely forgettable. It's the most generic Good vs Evil plot ever. NPCs have no character and neither does the guy you control for that matter. And speaking of the guy you control, you can actually control many different types of classes. They unlock one by one after completing the first few missions. It's rather pointless since they all unlock just a few missions in.So you can choose what class you want to play as and by choose I mean choose Druid or suffer. Why? Because combat sucks. Hit detection is terrible. Picking an archer might sound nice but it is not so nice when you realize it is impossibile to hit enemies yet enemy archers have perfect aim. Even melee sucks, you just go next to and enemy and mash attack and maybe hit one third of the time. Hit detection is down right broken.The only class that is worth playing is the Druid because she has a staff that can cast "homing magical bird missiles" and summon a golem to fight for you (although don't expect golem to do much, the AI is terrible). Even homing missiles don't hit all the time, they just circle around the enemy and dissipate but it is your only choice if you want to beat this game without losing your♥♥♥♥♥♥over the stupid combat.But even with the Druid and her gamebreaking weapon, the game is still boring. Because the way the game is designed is more like a corridor shooter than anything else. There are no side objectives and absolutely ZERO exploration. In fact it does that annoying thing where if you steer of the road, it counts down and fails your mission, all because you wanted to get out of the linear path and maybe go for a swim.Levels are short and all you have to do is get to the next objective. If your objective doesn't include killing enemies you can just ignore them and go the next waypoint and beat the mission. One guy wrote that this game had varied mission. Phwahaha, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game has only ONE mission: Get to the objective area and kill enemies in your path if they block you from getting to the objective area. Every single mission is this. Even escort missions are like this. I didn't even have to escort the guy I was suppose to protect, I just ignored him and went to the waypoint and he turned out fine.Don't waste your time on this one, there are so many other games to play.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I gave this game a not recommended not because it is a broken/non-playable game or because it is not good, but maybe because of some features that the game offers which put me off. If this game did not have all the problems/features I complained about in this review, it would of got a recommended from me A real classical game, can't believe this was created by Starbreeze Studios! My favorite game company. The game is really good on first impressions, I like that there are two campaigns. Light and Dark, I highly recommend first time players play it on Easy, as you can die allot! On the whole, the game is really cool, a great RPG experienceBut I must warn you, that the game is really glitchy and really put me off with all of its bugs and glitches, and the game can get pretty boring quickly, so, if you like RPG games like this with some clunky mechanics and glitches, then this is the game for you, if on the other hand, you like RPG's but you want a good solid game, then this game is not for you NOT RECOMMENDED :(  I am not recommending this because the game put me off, with all of its problems, but like I said if you like RPG's with some clunky mechanics and glitches then this game is for you, otherwise, don't bother! There are many other great RPG's like the Witcher series (Which is currently on sale - Summer Sale 2014)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Where should I start about this game.It cost me €0,69 and my life has been changed.It all began in the main menu when I was going to start a new adventure.The game gave me a choice if I wanted to play the light or dark campaign, because I'm an edgy guy I wanted to choose the dark campaign.Up untill this moment I thought the game was fine but then when I wanted to pick the dark campaign I couldn't because it was unavailable for some reason.Well alright I'll go with the light campaign not what I wanted to but oh well.Then I spawned and some random chick got blown up and then just disappeared.The moment I found out that collecting the maximum amount of gold each quest was more interesting then the quests and the whole storyline my whole view of the game was changed.This isn't an ordinary RPG, this game was made to see if you're persistent enough to collect all the gold.But this game does not only have action it also has some Mirror Edge like parkour.So not only can you ♥♥♥♥ up ugly goblins you also run around collecting gold like a maniac.12/10 Would play again for dark campaign gold collecting.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Changing my review... I was criticizing the publisher choice of including an adware, opening the browser to advertise Ravens Cry- but thankfully they came to their senses and removed it.Enclave is an oldschool action hack n' slash on the similar veins of Heretic II (a personal favorite of all time), Rune, Deathtrap Dungeon and the like- with nice controls, first and third person view, an intriguing storyline and a nice lore and setting that still looks rather nice on modern computers unlike so many other oldies. For me its a newfound classic, a game i hadn't the chance to play on release... so yeah, no nostalgia here. If you like any of the games mentioned, you're bound to love Enclave.

												This game is far better than I expected, when I first bought it on sale I expected a cheaply made, linear rpg.What I ended up getting was a well-made dungeon crawl that keeps me very entertained; with classic graphics, simple controls and easy but fun combat coupled with a complex story and some great voice acting, I find this is definitely a game for the western rpg fan or anyone who wants a return to the classic games of the late 90s and early 2000sIf I had to make a complaint it is only that the game requires some back-tracking but it keeps it relatively interesting with events that only occur when you return to various areas and creating reasons to explore.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												Where should I start about this game.It cost me €0,69 and my life has been changed.It all began in the main menu when I was going to start a new adventure.The game gave me a choice if I wanted to play the light or dark campaign, because I'm an edgy guy I wanted to choose the dark campaign.Up untill this moment I thought the game was fine but then when I wanted to pick the dark campaign I couldn't because it was unavailable for some reason.Well alright I'll go with the light campaign not what I wanted to but oh well.Then I spawned and some random chick got blown up and then just disappeared.The moment I found out that collecting the maximum amount of gold each quest was more interesting then the quests and the whole storyline my whole view of the game was changed.This isn't an ordinary RPG, this game was made to see if you're persistent enough to collect all the gold.But this game does not only have action it also has some Mirror Edge like parkour.So not only can you ♥♥♥♥ up ugly goblins you also run around collecting gold like a maniac.12/10 Would play again for dark campaign gold collecting.

												First off, this game is NOT worth full price.  I bought it for $0.50 with a coupon I got from badge crafting, and might have paid $2 or $3 at most for the content.This game runs fantastically smoothly on my potato and does look fairly good.  However, the controls, especially in combat, feel very inaccurate and inconsistent.  Evclave was basically a hack n slash the way I played it, just attacking continuously except to heal occasionally.  Sometime what you are supposed to do is very vague as well.  I got stuck on the second level because I had no idea what to do, and there weren't really any noticeable pointers toward what ended up being a cannon near me.Overall, this game is worth it with a discount, but has somewhat aggravating controls.  I'd recommend it if it's cheap because it is worth it when cheap.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												First released in 2002 on Microsoft's Xbox, Enclave later witnessed a PC release in 2003. Though Enclave is without a doubt not without its flaws, it's still a very enjoyable game that offers a considerable degree of replay value. Enclave picks up after the end of a brutal war between the Kingdom of Celenheim and the forces of the demon lord Vatar, known as the Dreg'Atar. During the final battle between these two warring factions, the wizard Zale gives his life to cast a spell that tears the land asunder, thus preventing the Dreg'Atar from sending reinforcements to aid their main force. One thousand years later however, the rift separating Celenheim from the rest of the land begins to close and Vatar prepares to rise once again to take control of his mighty armies. Although Enclave places little emphasis on character development, the game still manages to present a fairly interesting narrative, driven to a greater degree by the events of the story rather than the characters. Siding with either Celenheim or the forces of the Dreg'Atar outland tribes, you assume control of a collection of nameless characters who are entrusted with important tasks by their leaders, that eventually lead them on a journey across the rift and beyond. Key developments in the plot are depicted primarily through a number of short, in-game cut-scenes. While Enclave's story doesn't do anything spectacular, it does present a few unexpected twists and turns towards the end, resulting in a satisfying and decent plot that gives context to the main characters' actions. After choosing a side, the player embarks upon a number of missions that lead them through various locales, including deserted temples, castles, forested areas protected by elemental guardians and virtually every other setting that one might expect to come across in a typical D&D setting. Each mission usually involves getting from A to B whilst collecting gold and defeating the numerous enemies that block your path, in some cases acquiring several key items along the way.Between missions you'll be given an opportunity to change the selected player character as well as his/her equipment, with the ability to purchase new weapons and armour using the gold collected during missions. Characters are divided into one of three types, including those focusing upon melee attacks, ranged attacks and magic-based attacks. While melee characters are capable of wielding strong melee weapons and shields, their ranged combat skills are somewhat lacking. Ranged characters in comparison are adept in the use of bows, but have no means with which to block enemy attacks, while magic-based characters are able to attack foes from a distance as well as block enemy attacks at the expense of some mana. For the most part this formula works well and the missions feel well-paced with plenty of action, and moments of respite when required. Near the end of the game, the unavailability of checkpoints on the highest difficulty setting can become a minor annoyance, as you approach the final portion of a long mission, only for a key character to die, thus forcing you to restart the mission from the very beginning. None of the missions from either of the campaigns are all that long, but it’s still an issue all the same, if only because it’s a step in the wrong direction: one that’s directed towards the introduction of ‘artificial difficulty’. If you already figured out how to get past a section of a specific level and died during the next section, then why is there any need to repeat the former part of the level? Surely the player should be allowed to re-attempt only the part they failed at, rather than re-doing every area that they already demonstrated they know how to get past. After all, that’s exactly what happens on the default difficulty level. Repeating portions of a mission you’ve already done doesn’t add any extra difficulty – it just adds padding. A greater issue however is the mission design itself. Some missions are clearly geared towards a certain character, which becomes evident after the fifth failed attempt at making it past the third group of enemies encountered, after choosing a character whom the developers didn't seem to expect anyone to choose for that particular mission. A prime example of this can be seen in the penultimate mission from the Celenheim campaign, in which the player is presented at the start of the level with a powerful melee-focused enemy, as well as a minimum of two ranged combatants who can easily whittle down a magic-based character's mana by forcing them to stop incoming attacks, before reducing their health to zero within mere seconds. Hit detection issues are also present, though this is more noticeable when playing as a ranged character.Most of the time the AI does a good job of presenting you with clever and fierce adversaries to fight, but on rare occasions enemies will freeze up and stand on the spot until you move past a certain invisible line drawn on the ground. Other times enemies can be easily fooled into committing suicide by walking into environmental hazards. One mission in which this can be put into practice sees the player coming to shore and arriving on a beach guarded by a few ranged combatants. If the player moves close enough to each one, they'll draw their melee weapons and proceed to follow the player wherever they go – including into the water, which proves fatal for them (though for some reason, not the player). Despite these flaws, Enclave's gameplay is still a very fun and enjoyable experience, and the option of replaying most of the missions as any character from that mission's respective campaign ensures a great deal of replay value, even if this can sometimes present some scenarios that are nearly impossible for certain characters to overcome. Then again, experimenting is fun right? Most of the character models are fairly well detailed, though some of the characters' faces are lacking in areas and look too basic in comparison to the rest of the model. Environments also benefit from a high-level of detail and lighting effects, the latter which often create a powerful atmosphere for each setting. Water has been surprisingly well animated and; from a distance; looks fantastic. A scene that stands out as a prime example of this can be found during a mission titled 'The Sanctuary' while staring out towards a lake set against the backdrop of a golden sunset, as the sunlight reflects of the water. Enclave features a subtle, if well-crafted soundtrack. Each track lends itself to give each setting a unique feel, even though a number of tracks are re-used for certain missions. Dynamic music adjusts to fit the situation, with its tempo increasing and decreasing when the player is in combat and out of combat respectively. The sounds of bowstrings being drawn, swords clashing and explosions going off all sound as they should. The majority of characters have also been well-voiced, though a few characters seem to have suffered in cases where their voice actor/actress has over-exaggerated and tried too hard. Enclave is a game that; despite its flaws; ends up being a relatively solid game with decent gameplay and an interesting plot to back it up. A fun game worth purchasing, even if it is a little rough around the edges.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
												Enclave is a fast paced and unforgiving game. Imho it is quite underrated and misrepresented. First of all it´s not an RPG game...Basically you have a campaign with a mission after another. Instead of locking you into on character you can swap between them at beginning of any missions. You are not locked into any gear decisions either. So you dont buy and sell stuff. You simply can start with any item combo that correlates with the accumulated wealth so far. After completing certain missions, you unlock new tier of items. This freedom of choice made the game quite enjoyable.In Enclave as most enemies are capable of wiping you pretty fast on hard difficulty. An assasin can simply hit you once in the head with an arrow or a melee charracter can bash you off a cliff. Therefore, you must always be on your toes. Most maps are filled with traps that can kill you instantly. While many whine about these, practically every one of these can be spotted. You just have to be alert.There are many type of maps from simple towns, into caves and hounted houses. Level design is boosted by top notch music. Voice acting is also decent to say the least. Perhaps the most memorable map was Arc Moor fortress in light campaign. It is located in the middle of a volcano with only a narrow bridge leading to it. Naturally you have to get in while dodging arrows while trying to kite those heavy armored melees.There found only 2 major flaws in this game. 1. Swimming with mlook. When you turn, your movement momentarely stops. This makes swimming dreadfull on PC. 2. AI cant find paths in certain areas. Many also complained about no saves. On hard difficulty you dont even have checkpoints. So you have to able to go in, kill your target, pick that expensive loot and get away alive. Makes it way more thrilling.Naturally Enclave Graphics are outdated but for 2,5€ sale this game was a pretty neat bargain. It's actually best buy for me since Psychonauts. While it aint your basic 90 metascore game, it sure shouldn´t be as low as 71.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game, sadly it's not the case. For this price I'd say go ahead and try it out but don't expect too much.Let's begin with the good sides :+ The graphics are really nice looking. I'm not being sarcastic^^, it's dated of course but it aged very well+ Lots of secrets areas to discover, exploration while limited is rewarded+ Two campaigns (Light and Dark)+ Multiples characters and weapon unlocked during the game+ The gameplay is kinda fun I guess, when it's not frustrating (we'll get to that in a minute)+ Targeted damages+ Some ideas are really cool like the fact you can shoot multiples arrows from your bow (even if I didn't understand how it works exactly and ended up wasting a lot of arrows), so I'll see which other games this studio has made, they might be cool if they improved from this one (Edit: Actually, they did good games after that! https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Starbreeze_Studios ).And now for the bad sides. These are small gripes that adds up and make the game really frustrating to play in the end :- Combats (especially melee) feels really clunky with no sense of impact. If it wasn't for the damage counts displayed over enemies and player, I wouldn't even know when I hit or being hit. In melee, you just mash your mouse in hope to hit the enemies, there is absolutely 0 strategy involvedWhen ranged, you wait for your bow/crossbow to be loaded, then you shoot to see the enemy move at that exact moment, back to the waiting... It's infuriating when you have to shoot an archer on a roof.Sometimes, when an enemy is too close to you, the arrow pass right through its body without dealing any damage- Switching weapons takes forever- No sense of achievement when you kill an enemy because there's no XP, loot (usually) or anything -> ok, this one depends on your tastes. I feel like the game would have benefited from some minor RPG elements- Escort missions that you lose if the NPC gets killed- Once you lose a mission, you have to restart it all over again, which isn't fun one bit... I'm not against difficulty but the combats feels so random that I don't feel like I learn from my errors or something, it just feels like I have to start over for no reason.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Bought this game at a cut price; such a classic style Action RPG. Great combat, solid controls which are easy to learn and remember. Haven't got a controller to work with it yet, but with programs like XPadder, I don't see why it would be difficult; not necessary, but it shouldn't be too hard if you really dislike keyboard and mouse.The only downside is the low graphical quality; which is understandable when you consider the 2003 release date. Character models are pretty good for the age, but landscape textures are very blurred. Resolution goes up to 1080p, which is awesome, and for a port, the options menu is pretty detailed.I probably wouldn't recommend you buy this game at £3.99, since the game is so old now, that just sounds unnecessarily high. Like I said, I bought this in a sale and it cost me £1.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												When Enclave came out in 2003 I was engaged in other pursuits and games, so it came and passed fairly under my radar. I managed to snatch it in a promo campaign so with fresh eyes I gave it a go. Having played first few missions, my first impressions are positive. Yes, even after all this time, after more than 10 years, two more generations of consoles and after unimaginable enhancment in overall quality of graphic, production, but playability also, I can say I can still feel the solid (for its time, of course) design and interesting gameplay mechanics. What's different than current standards is that the game is devided in small separate areas with missions in them, rather than one seemingly conected open world. But the missions are short, have a coherency in the level design and can be replayed ad infinitum, if you left some secret with gold hidden. The combat is fun and diverse, 'cause you can pick one of many characters (classes) which all have several different spots for different equipment, so your options of killing baddies are fairly broad.The story is fairly standard fantasy fare with lots of strange names and metric tones of exposition in the begining. If you like the genre, it seems standard entertainment, but if you find all the apostrophes annoying, you won't like it. So overal verdict: much more things are positive, than negative, so a solid "yes" recomendation. If you manage to snatch it in some sale and like the 3d action RPG-light genre, you can find enjoyment in the game. If not, then there's no place for such an old game in todays saturated market.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Nice graphics for the time,♥♥♥♥♥♥gameplay for the ages.For it's era it has nice graphics and they knew that. They push the graphics all over your face. Every menu transition has overly elaborate and unnecessary transition animations. But now that it is a decade later and the graphics have aged all of these are just tedious instead. The game is an obvious console showcase title, and I could tell this was originally a console game just from the menu screen without prior knowledge. It just feels like a console game.Music is nothing special, I forget all about it about in 5 seconds as soon as I quit the game.Story is non-existant. Sure there is a huge plot dump with cutscenes and inter-mission logs but it is entirely forgettable. It's the most generic Good vs Evil plot ever. NPCs have no character and neither does the guy you control for that matter. And speaking of the guy you control, you can actually control many different types of classes. They unlock one by one after completing the first few missions. It's rather pointless since they all unlock just a few missions in.So you can choose what class you want to play as and by choose I mean choose Druid or suffer. Why? Because combat sucks. Hit detection is terrible. Picking an archer might sound nice but it is not so nice when you realize it is impossibile to hit enemies yet enemy archers have perfect aim. Even melee sucks, you just go next to and enemy and mash attack and maybe hit one third of the time. Hit detection is down right broken.The only class that is worth playing is the Druid because she has a staff that can cast "homing magical bird missiles" and summon a golem to fight for you (although don't expect golem to do much, the AI is terrible). Even homing missiles don't hit all the time, they just circle around the enemy and dissipate but it is your only choice if you want to beat this game without losing your♥♥♥♥♥♥over the stupid combat.But even with the Druid and her gamebreaking weapon, the game is still boring. Because the way the game is designed is more like a corridor shooter than anything else. There are no side objectives and absolutely ZERO exploration. In fact it does that annoying thing where if you steer of the road, it counts down and fails your mission, all because you wanted to get out of the linear path and maybe go for a swim.Levels are short and all you have to do is get to the next objective. If your objective doesn't include killing enemies you can just ignore them and go the next waypoint and beat the mission. One guy wrote that this game had varied mission. Phwahaha, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game has only ONE mission: Get to the objective area and kill enemies in your path if they block you from getting to the objective area. Every single mission is this. Even escort missions are like this. I didn't even have to escort the guy I was suppose to protect, I just ignored him and went to the waypoint and he turned out fine.Don't waste your time on this one, there are so many other games to play.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												I read weird reviews about how the game tries to make pop-up ads come on, but as I saw myself and as someone else who I saw reviewd this game, it doesn't do that anymore. I don't even know why that's a big deal in the first place. Anyway, this game was kind of fun. It had its moments and it was surprisingly difficult. It suffered from a lot of gameplay and level design issues. At times the game mechancis made the experience frustrating, although in the end the hardest levels were not impossible, but required immense precision and determination in order to overcome the questionable gaming mechanics and level design. Like some other people said before; collecting gold is KEY. It's the only way to have good equipment in the game. Thankfully you can replay levels to collect more gold in order to have better equipment before moving on to the next level. Ther are 14 missions and I missed like 2000 gold, but I was able to get the best equipment for each character. Anyway, it's a good time waster if you wait for it to be on 95% off, like I did. Otherwise I don't think it's worth 4.99.

												They must have fixed the advertizement that everyone is complaining about, but that still doesn't fix the game. The story is lack luster, the voice actors often sound like they are reading straight from the script, and the hit box is all wonky.The StoryThe game feels like a rehashing of a rehashing, there is no inovtaion to the story its just "It's time for good people versus bad people." Right away they open up telling you about the Rift, sort of, all you really get isthe people to one side are the good guys and the other side are the bad guys. Theres some story about a Wizard and a Demon that created the rift but the exposition felt long and the voice over was so terrible it put my dogs to sleep.The voice acting:Good God. It's almost like they decided to hand their script of to family members with no prior training and have them read it. Everytime some one speak I feel like I'm watching the original Star Trek and Shatner is playing all the parts. There is frequent pauses, and enflexions on the wrong words changing the meaning of sentences in the worst possible way, somtimes it even goes so far as to have to characters talk over each other; but hey, there's subtitles right? So if all else fails and you can stomache the terrible hit box you can always just read what they're saying instead.The Hit Box:I don't even understand how some people think this game is even playable.The hit box is minimal and if the enemy is backing up, even if that means they are backing up into a wall, there is no box at all. On top of that if you happen to hit something esle first; e.g. a wall, then it will just pass right through the enemy entirely, which is a problem because most of the game you're in a freaking corridor.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
 Enclave [Warning: Long review]  Enclave is a third-person action game in which you can play as part of either the good or evil armies in an epic fantasy conflict. Though you'll begin on either side with a single playable character, you'll later rescue or unlock other character classes with various melee, ranged, or magic-based attacks that they can use to defeat their enemies.But fighting isn't very precise, or very fun, in Enclave, since the game has unreliable hit detection; sometimes arrows and swords will pass right through your enemies, and your enemies' attacks will occasionally fly right through your shield (if you're carrying one) and damage you. In addition, your characters generally don't fight very quickly; most ranged weapons take a while to reload, and most melee attacks consist of a series of slow-moving, preset animations that take a while to conclude and leave you vulnerable to a counterattack. And most of Enclave's characters don't move very quickly either, so you can basically expect to take hits from your enemies no matter what, especially when multiple enemies swarm you (as they often do in later levels of the game). Your character can pick up and drink health potions, but you'll do this just as slowly as you fight, run, or change weapons, so this can be of limited use in small areas crowded by multiple enemies.Enclave was an extremely difficult game on the Xbox, and its difficulty has been toned down in the PC version so that enemies don't kill you with a single blow, but you'll still suffer severe damage when hit by unseen traps for the first time, and you'll most likely find the game's limited save-game system to be frustrating. You can save only at predetermined safe areas, which, in certain levels, are few and far between. Make a wrong move or get mobbed by too many enemies, and you'll be sent all the way back to your previous save point. In addition, Enclave's levels, while not particularly huge, are still fairly big and will often require you to backtrack through them several times. It's safe to say that Enclave would have been a much less frustrating game to play if it had featured both a better save-game system and an in-game map. Enclave isn't a particularly lengthy game otherwise, and since it has no multiplayer options, you may not get much out of the game in the long run.In many of the game's levels, you'll need to backtrack to find a particular item or enemy or to lead a computer-controlled companion to a specific goal area. Unfortunately, Enclave's AI for both allies and enemies is inconsistent and occasionally quite bad. Any allies you must lead or escort through a level will stop dead in their tracks if faced with even a small obstacle. There's no way to issue any commands to your allies, so you'll often have to leave them behind, even if they were supposed to help you fight your way through the level.The enemy AI is usually good about attacking you when you come within range, and some enemies will even taunt you when they have you outnumbered. However, some enemies will get stuck on environmental objects as they try to follow you around them, and other times, if you back away from them a short distance, they'll simply stand still for no good reason. When this happens, they're easier to pick off than when they mob your slow-moving character who's poorly equipped to handle attacks from all sides, but the game's unreliable AI and equally unreliable control make for fights that are mostly unsatisfying.It's too bad that Enclave has these problems, because its presentation is otherwise quite impressive. The game's sound effects and voice acting are passable, but you may be too busy paying attention to Enclave's great soundtrack to notice. The game's somber, oppressive music does a great job of providing atmosphere for Enclave's often-dark, gothic fantasy setting (which consists of dimly lit fortresses, secret passages, and ancient temples of evil, among other things). Enclave also looks extremely good. Though it was originally developed for Microsoft's Xbox console, it holds up quite well on the PC. Even though the game's textures begin to show seams and jagged edges if you play the game at resolutions of 1024x768 or higher, the quality of Enclave's graphics and design is unmistakable. The game's developers clearly put a lot of effort into creating the detailed textures that adorn its levels and its highly detailed characters, who speak with animated facial expressions in the in-engine cutscenes. Though many of the game's levels consist of generic-seeming fantasy locales, such as a dungeon, a temple, and a medieval town, their good texture work and lighting, especially shadows cast from torchlight, make even the most run-down areas look good. In fact, some of Enclave's environments look surprisingly original, even artistic, such as an abandoned sorceress's lair that's filled with both deadly traps and breakable glass cages of fluttering butterflies.Though the game's developers clearly put a lot of work into the way the game looks and sounds, Enclave's gameplay just doesn't measure up to its presentation. If you do pick up a copy of the game, you'll probably appreciate Enclave's sound and graphics, but you may also find that the game itself has too many problems to be enjoyable for long. Enemy AI in this game was quite well done; a challenge to play against and that is what Starbreeze Studios needed to do with this game, is make a challenging AI. The AI is quite clever. Enemy archers will draw their blades for close quarters combat and take cover during reloads. Enemy soldiers will draw their shields to defend against your arrows. Overall the AI provides for challenging opponents in the game. Sorry for this really long review XD

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												First released in 2002 on Microsoft's Xbox, Enclave later witnessed a PC release in 2003. Though Enclave is without a doubt not without its flaws, it's still a very enjoyable game that offers a considerable degree of replay value. Enclave picks up after the end of a brutal war between the Kingdom of Celenheim and the forces of the demon lord Vatar, known as the Dreg'Atar. During the final battle between these two warring factions, the wizard Zale gives his life to cast a spell that tears the land asunder, thus preventing the Dreg'Atar from sending reinforcements to aid their main force. One thousand years later however, the rift separating Celenheim from the rest of the land begins to close and Vatar prepares to rise once again to take control of his mighty armies. Although Enclave places little emphasis on character development, the game still manages to present a fairly interesting narrative, driven to a greater degree by the events of the story rather than the characters. Siding with either Celenheim or the forces of the Dreg'Atar outland tribes, you assume control of a collection of nameless characters who are entrusted with important tasks by their leaders, that eventually lead them on a journey across the rift and beyond. Key developments in the plot are depicted primarily through a number of short, in-game cut-scenes. While Enclave's story doesn't do anything spectacular, it does present a few unexpected twists and turns towards the end, resulting in a satisfying and decent plot that gives context to the main characters' actions. After choosing a side, the player embarks upon a number of missions that lead them through various locales, including deserted temples, castles, forested areas protected by elemental guardians and virtually every other setting that one might expect to come across in a typical D&D setting. Each mission usually involves getting from A to B whilst collecting gold and defeating the numerous enemies that block your path, in some cases acquiring several key items along the way.Between missions you'll be given an opportunity to change the selected player character as well as his/her equipment, with the ability to purchase new weapons and armour using the gold collected during missions. Characters are divided into one of three types, including those focusing upon melee attacks, ranged attacks and magic-based attacks. While melee characters are capable of wielding strong melee weapons and shields, their ranged combat skills are somewhat lacking. Ranged characters in comparison are adept in the use of bows, but have no means with which to block enemy attacks, while magic-based characters are able to attack foes from a distance as well as block enemy attacks at the expense of some mana. For the most part this formula works well and the missions feel well-paced with plenty of action, and moments of respite when required. Near the end of the game, the unavailability of checkpoints on the highest difficulty setting can become a minor annoyance, as you approach the final portion of a long mission, only for a key character to die, thus forcing you to restart the mission from the very beginning. None of the missions from either of the campaigns are all that long, but it’s still an issue all the same, if only because it’s a step in the wrong direction: one that’s directed towards the introduction of ‘artificial difficulty’. If you already figured out how to get past a section of a specific level and died during the next section, then why is there any need to repeat the former part of the level? Surely the player should be allowed to re-attempt only the part they failed at, rather than re-doing every area that they already demonstrated they know how to get past. After all, that’s exactly what happens on the default difficulty level. Repeating portions of a mission you’ve already done doesn’t add any extra difficulty – it just adds padding. A greater issue however is the mission design itself. Some missions are clearly geared towards a certain character, which becomes evident after the fifth failed attempt at making it past the third group of enemies encountered, after choosing a character whom the developers didn't seem to expect anyone to choose for that particular mission. A prime example of this can be seen in the penultimate mission from the Celenheim campaign, in which the player is presented at the start of the level with a powerful melee-focused enemy, as well as a minimum of two ranged combatants who can easily whittle down a magic-based character's mana by forcing them to stop incoming attacks, before reducing their health to zero within mere seconds. Hit detection issues are also present, though this is more noticeable when playing as a ranged character.Most of the time the AI does a good job of presenting you with clever and fierce adversaries to fight, but on rare occasions enemies will freeze up and stand on the spot until you move past a certain invisible line drawn on the ground. Other times enemies can be easily fooled into committing suicide by walking into environmental hazards. One mission in which this can be put into practice sees the player coming to shore and arriving on a beach guarded by a few ranged combatants. If the player moves close enough to each one, they'll draw their melee weapons and proceed to follow the player wherever they go – including into the water, which proves fatal for them (though for some reason, not the player). Despite these flaws, Enclave's gameplay is still a very fun and enjoyable experience, and the option of replaying most of the missions as any character from that mission's respective campaign ensures a great deal of replay value, even if this can sometimes present some scenarios that are nearly impossible for certain characters to overcome. Then again, experimenting is fun right? Most of the character models are fairly well detailed, though some of the characters' faces are lacking in areas and look too basic in comparison to the rest of the model. Environments also benefit from a high-level of detail and lighting effects, the latter which often create a powerful atmosphere for each setting. Water has been surprisingly well animated and; from a distance; looks fantastic. A scene that stands out as a prime example of this can be found during a mission titled 'The Sanctuary' while staring out towards a lake set against the backdrop of a golden sunset, as the sunlight reflects of the water. Enclave features a subtle, if well-crafted soundtrack. Each track lends itself to give each setting a unique feel, even though a number of tracks are re-used for certain missions. Dynamic music adjusts to fit the situation, with its tempo increasing and decreasing when the player is in combat and out of combat respectively. The sounds of bowstrings being drawn, swords clashing and explosions going off all sound as they should. The majority of characters have also been well-voiced, though a few characters seem to have suffered in cases where their voice actor/actress has over-exaggerated and tried too hard. Enclave is a game that; despite its flaws; ends up being a relatively solid game with decent gameplay and an interesting plot to back it up. A fun game worth purchasing, even if it is a little rough around the edges.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												The medieval fantasy setting is well done, the levels are short, but well designed, the voice acting is pretty good.  Character classes have distinct styles, visually and functionally.  The money/loot/equip system makes you balance the weapons, armor, and ammo in your loadout, since you can't change it during play, though you can occasionally pick up extra things during a level.Unfortunately, the age and porting shows on this game.  Melee combat is clunky, blocking is randomly effective, ranged combat is an exercise in frustration.  All the enemies are faster than you but the AI is rudimentary. The menus are keyboard navigation only, an artifact of the porting, I presume. There are occasional unrecoverable errors and CTD's, some of which go away if you change to OpenGL, some if you change back to Direct3D8.Overall, it's an average game suffering from a mediocre porting.  For a single-player fantasy action/adventure game, it's brief, but decent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
												Enclave is a fast paced and unforgiving game. Imho it is quite underrated and misrepresented. First of all it´s not an RPG game...Basically you have a campaign with a mission after another. Instead of locking you into on character you can swap between them at beginning of any missions. You are not locked into any gear decisions either. So you dont buy and sell stuff. You simply can start with any item combo that correlates with the accumulated wealth so far. After completing certain missions, you unlock new tier of items. This freedom of choice made the game quite enjoyable.In Enclave as most enemies are capable of wiping you pretty fast on hard difficulty. An assasin can simply hit you once in the head with an arrow or a melee charracter can bash you off a cliff. Therefore, you must always be on your toes. Most maps are filled with traps that can kill you instantly. While many whine about these, practically every one of these can be spotted. You just have to be alert.There are many type of maps from simple towns, into caves and hounted houses. Level design is boosted by top notch music. Voice acting is also decent to say the least. Perhaps the most memorable map was Arc Moor fortress in light campaign. It is located in the middle of a volcano with only a narrow bridge leading to it. Naturally you have to get in while dodging arrows while trying to kite those heavy armored melees.There found only 2 major flaws in this game. 1. Swimming with mlook. When you turn, your movement momentarely stops. This makes swimming dreadfull on PC. 2. AI cant find paths in certain areas. Many also complained about no saves. On hard difficulty you dont even have checkpoints. So you have to able to go in, kill your target, pick that expensive loot and get away alive. Makes it way more thrilling.Naturally Enclave Graphics are outdated but for 2,5€ sale this game was a pretty neat bargain. It's actually best buy for me since Psychonauts. While it aint your basic 90 metascore game, it sure shouldn´t be as low as 71.
